Stuffed animals, T-shirts and flowers meant for members of the New Kids on the Block were sent to a home-away-from-home for families of seriously ill children in Pittsburgh hospitals. The carload of presents intended for the teen-age singing group, who played concerts over the weekend near Pittsburgh, were left by fans at the Star Lake Amphitheatre in Washington County. Parents of the singers donated the gifts to the Ronald McDonald House, a home for the families of seriously ill children. Before Friday's concert, members of the group met with some of the children, including the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, Stormie Jones of Texas, who is under treatment at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh.

TV reporter Charles Kuralt has turned down a request by a group of archaeologists to dig up the front lawn of his vacation house. In a letter to Wesleyan University archaeology professor John Pfeiffer, the television newsman told the scholars he is not interested in what might lie beneath the lush, green turf, Pfeiffer said Saturday. Pfeiffer is leading a crew of Wesleyan University graduate students who are excavating sections of an 18th- and 19th-century industrial complex at the mouth of Falls River in Essex. They believe Kuralt's lawn, several hundred yards upstream from the site, could hold clues to the development of the area as a 19th-century ivory processing center. The professor said Kuralt believed his property had held nothing more than a bicycle factory. ``He felt that archaeology wouldn't tell him anything that he didn't already know,'' Pfeiffer said. A woman who answered the phone Sunday at CBS news in New York said Kuralt had left for the day, and there was no answer Sunday afternoon at Kuralt's home telephone in Essex. The archaeologists had written Kuralt in May asking for permission to dig a few small ``test pits'' in the lawn, which they believe could conceal a trove of ivory notions such as eyelets, combs and perhaps even fragments of billiard balls.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed, 21 Injured in Unrest, Bombings
DOC.TEXT: Three explosions in Johannesburg and scattered violence in the eastern province of Natal have claimed the lives of seven blacks and resulted in 21 injuries, police said Sunday. The most serious attack was at a hotel bar frequented by blacks in the Johannesburg suburb of Roodepoort, where a grenade exploded late Saturday night, killing one and injuring 21, police said. A chef at the Roodepoort Hotel, Violet Cheki, said she saw a white man open the door to the bar and roll an object into a crowd of about 100 people just before the blast. In the same area, a hotel bar where all the patrons were white was bombed with explosives before dawn Saturday, killing a black waiter. Police said there also was an explosion Saturday at the suburban Johannesburg home of a right-wing white, Hans Binneman. No one was injured. No one claimed responsibility for any of the weekend attacks. However, white extremists have issued statements claiming responsibility for a recent spate of bombings in Johannesburg aimed at blacks and whites who oppose apartheid. Police have detained nine whites for questioning, but no one has been charged. Pro-apartheid whites have vowed to resist President F.W. de Klerk's plans to dismantle the apartheid system of racial segregation and share power with the 30-million black majority. Robert van Tonder, leader of the right-wing Boer State Party, said: ``All these blasts, unrest and violence are due to the government reforms.'' ``They (the government) created a climate of suspicion, lack of confidence and anarchy,'' van Tonder told the independent South African Press Association. The African National Congress, the leading black opposition group, has accused the government of not taking firm action against right-wingers suspected of violence. In Natal, two policemen were among five blacks killed, according to the police unrest report, which covers incidents from the previous 24 hours. One policeman was stabbed to death near Pietermaritzburg and the other was fatally shot in Umlazi outside Durban. Two men were shot to death and the body of another man was found in three separate incidents, the report added. More than 4,000 blacks have been killed in factional violence in Natal since 1986. The main combatants are supporters of the ANC and Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu poltical party headed by Mangosuthu Buthelezi. Both sides oppose apartheid, but disagree on tactics and have many youthful supporters they cannot control.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher and Academics Analyze Germany's Character
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher secretly gathered leading academics to discuss the Germans and explore traits traditionally attributed to them such as ``angst, aggressive bullying (and) egotism,'' it was revealed Sunday. Mrs. Thatcher's think tank concluded that while the Germans have changed, the future was uncertain. Meanwhile, they decided, ``we should be nice to the Germans.'' A summary of the March 24 meeting at Mrs. Thatcher's country house, Chequers, was written by her private secretary, Charles Powell. It was published in full in The Independent on Sunday. It was not clear how the paper obtained a copy of the report. But Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, who attended the meeting, confirmed the text's accuracy. ``We started by talking about the Germans and their characteristics,'' Powell wrote, listing ``angst, aggressiveness bullying, egotism, inferiority complex, sentimentality.'' ``But there was a strong school of thought among those present that today's Germans were very different,'' and that after World War II, militarism and thirst for conquests disappeared. ``Education and the writing of history had changed ... We should have no real worries about them,'' he reportedly wrote. Not everyone agreed, however. ``It still had to be asked how a cultured and cultivated nation had allowed itself to be brainwashed into barbarism. If it had happened once, could it not happen again?'' the summary said. Even today, it said, ``The way the Germans threw their weight about in the European Community suggested that a lot had still not changed ... German behavior in the EC _ `we pay so we must have our way' _ was seen by some as a harbinger of Germany's economic dominance over Western Europe.'' The new Germany has never been tested by calamity, the document said. ``No one (at the meeting) had serious misgivings about the present leaders or political elite of Germany. But what about 10, 15 or 20 years from now?'' ``No formal conclusions were drawn,'' the summary said, but ``the weight of the evidence and the argument favored those who were optimistic about life in a united Germany. ... When it came to failings and unhelpful characteristics, the Germans had their share and perhaps more, but in contrast to the past, they were much readier to recognize and admit this themselves.'' ``The overall message was unmistakable; we should be nice to the Germans. But even the optimists had some unease, not for the present and the immediate future, but for what might lie further down the road than we can yet see.'' The participants, according to the newspaper, included Mrs. Thatcher, historian Hugh Trevor-Roper, Oxford University's Norman Stone, American Professors Fritz Stern of Columbia University and Gordon Craig of Harvard, journalist Timothy Garton Ash, and George Urban, former research director at Radio Free Europe. The summary was published amid political upheaval over the resignation of Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley for comments made about Germany, and opposition politicians were quick to accuse Mrs. Thatcher of insulting a friendly ally. The Labor Party's Gerald Kaufman said it was an ``offensive farce'' for senior Cabinet ministers to ``sit around pulling the Germans to pieces.'' But Hurd saw nothing wrong with a brainstorming session about the implications of a momentous event such as the unification of Germany. The first step toward unification came with economic union of the German states on July 1 and a full merger will come after all-German elections, expected in December. What mattered, Hurd told BBC-TV, was that the experts' verdict on Germany was positive. It was virtually ``a fantasy to suppose that we're going to be faced with a new Hitler, or a new Gestapo,'' he said. ``We can really dismiss that as a possibility.'' Mrs. Thatcher's views did not appear in the summary, but she has voiced misgivings about the economic might of a united Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Boesak to Reconsider Resignation During 3-Week Leave
DOC.TEXT: Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent activist who resigned his church posts after reports he had an affair with a married woman, is reconsidering his decision to quit, his lawyer said Sunday. Church leaders at the mixed-race branch of the Dutch Reformed Church in Bellville outside Cape Town said at a service Sunday they ``would be grateful'' if Boesak decides to return after his three-week leave of absence. Boesak is ``much loved by all of us,'' said Johan Retief, a co-minister at the church. Many congregants wept during the service and expressed support for Boesak. However, graffiti on Boesak's office next to the church made sexually explicit references to the alleged affair between the minister and Elna Botha, a producer for government-run television. Boesak was not at church Sunday. But his lawyer, Essa Moosa, said Boesak will ``reflect seriously on his position over the next few weeks and come to a considered decision with regard to his resignation.'' Boesak, one of South Africa's best known anti-apartheid leaders, is a powerful speaker who is often at the front of anti-government marches and demonstrations. He has strong ties to the African National Congress, the country's leading opposition group, and many observers believe he has political ambitions. He tearfully resigned his post in a July 8 sermon following newspaper reports of the alleged affair. The newspapers said Boesak's wife, Dorothy, had tipped them off, and that reporters confronted Boesak at a Cape Town hotel. Boesak made no reference to Mrs. Botha in his resignation speech, but said: ``This is one of the darkest days of my life.'' ``I am deeply sorry for the the pain I have caused,'' he said. Boesak also serves as president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, an international body of Protestant churches. Retief said he did not know if Boesak had given up that post. Boesak, married for more than 20 years, was temporarily suspended from his church posts in 1985 after he was romantically linked to a church secretary. He was reinstated and acknowledged a ``special relationship'' with the woman. The Sunday Times of Johannesburg reported that Mrs. Botha had left her husband and gone to Atlanta and that Boesak would join her shortly. Mrs. Botha's husband, television newscaster Colin Fluxman, was taken off the air last week after breaking down as he read an item about the alleged relationship between his wife and Boesak.

DOC.HEAD: Bolshoi Dances `Romeo'
DOC.TEXT: The Bolshoi Ballet proves that sets and props aren't needed to tell the story of ``Romeo and Juliet'' dramatically and beautifully in dance. The company, dancing at the New York State Theater, presented its second full-evening ballet here, the first stop on a seven-city U.S. tour. On Saturday night, Yuri Posokhov and Lyudmila Semenyaka danced Romeo and Juliet with youthful passion. Posokhov enters, dances a solo. Then Mikhail Sharkov as Mercutio enters and dances. Sharkov is dressed in white and has the build and dash of a hero. One wonders for a moment whether he's Romeo. But Posokhov's slim build and darting intensity make him look, appropriately, very young. Semenyaka dances a slightly more mature Juliet. When she runs to her nurse after she has fallen in love at first sight with Romeo, she doesn't throw herself into the nurse's arms like a confused child but grabs her arms. One woman is telling another the news. Semenyaka's dancing looks very young and fresh. She danced with the Bolshoi here in 1979 and 1987. Each duet is different in mood. The balcony scene young passionate love, the wedding scene chaste, the wedding morning scene tender, the reunion in the tomb scene joyful on her part, physical exertion after taking poison on his part. Yuri Grigorovich, artistic director of the Bolshoi, choreographed ``Romeo and Juliet'' to Prokofiev's music for the Paris Opera Ballet in 1978. That version transferred to the Bolshoi a year later. It changes a few plot details from the ballet versions usually seen. The newly married Romeo doesn't hold back Mercutio in his duel with Juliet's brother, Tybalt. Here he grabs Tybalt's shoulder but Tybalt is able to stab Mercutio in the back, a nicer touch. There's more than the usual amount of dancing by corps de ballet in this version. The Bolshoi's male dancers are strong and virile. Grigorovich's ballet steps and patterns aren't as varied and nuanced as some choreographers. One gets more of a sense of repetition with him. But the overall architecture of the ballet is admirable and he is excellent at choreographing for many couples who fill the stage. The backdrop has sweeps of draped cloth, with different lighting. A projection of a doorway indicates Friar Laurence's premises. Yuri Vetrov danced the friar, who lifts and carries Juliet in this production. There's no balcony and no bed in Juliet's bedroom. Oddly, they aren't needed. Dancers get up from their knees or lie on the floor. Juliet changes costumes but wears her Juliet cap all the time, even in bed. Aleksei Dovgopoly danced Paris with flair, not making him a wimp. Aleksandr Vetrov was excellently haughty and audacious as Tybalt.

DOC.HEAD: Baptist Newsmen's Ouster Attempt Ends Hopes for Bloodless Conservative Coup
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Baptists who established control over the nation's largest Protestant denomination began flexing their authority and promptly sparked a clash over press freedom. The fundamentalist-moderate power struggle over the past decade for control of the Southern Baptist Convention reached a watershed last month when moderates failed in what was viewed as a last-ditch effort to balance leadership. And only about 24 hours after a fundamentalist Texas minister was installed as convention president, two editors of the Baptist Press were asked to resign. They refused, setting up a meeting Tuesday at Baptist headquarters here that some ministers say will tell a lot about how conservatives plan to lead the denomination's flock of nearly 15 million members. ``We all are waiting to see who's next,'' said the Rev. Roy Honeycutt, president of Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in Louisville, Ky. ``For all practical purposes, I assume they've now won the battle they've set out to win in 1979.'' Ordered to quit were editors Alvin C. Shackleford, 58, and Dan Martin, 51. Critics say that under them, the news service has become biased in favor of moderates. Both have asked for time to be heard at Tuesday's hearing of the 77-member executive committee. Martin said his refusal to quit has put Southern Baptist conservatives in a tough spot: Their coup can't be bloodless. ``They don't want to fire anybody. That leaves this situation a little ambivalent,'' he said. Executive Committee President Harold C. Bennett, who called the meeting, was at a conference in North Carolina and couldn't be reached for comment, a secretary in his office said Friday. He did not return a phone message left at his Nashville home Sunday. Newly elected Southern Baptist Convention President Morris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, also was out of town, a staff member said. In the past, Baptist debate has centered on religious subjects like whether the Bible should be considered to be literally true in all respects. But lately is has fallen on secular topics, such as the amount of coverge Baptist Press has given moderate ministers vs. conservatives. Television journalist Bill Moyers, a lifelong Southern Baptist, has leaped to the aid of the editors. In a letter to state Baptist news editors, Moyers attacked Houston judge Paul Pressler, a fundamentalist leader who has spearheaded the fight against the two editors. Moyers described Pressler, vice chairman of the 77-member executive committee, as a ``petty tyrant.'' ``He rules the Southern Baptist Convention like a swaggering Caesar, breaking good men when it pleases him,'' said Moyers, who defended the editors as unwilling to slant their reporting. Pressler was out of the country and unavailable for comment before the meeting. The Rev. Fred Wolfe, a pastor at Cottage Hill Baptist Church in Mobile, Ala., and executive committee treasurer, said he and five others suggested to Bennett that the editors be ousted. ``Real or perceived, there's strong feeling among conservatives that Baptist Press has been pro-moderate in the last 12 years,'' Wolfe said. ``I can assure you that Mr. Shackleford and Mr. Martin knew there was a real problem with Baptist Press for a long period of time.'' Moderates say the problem is that Southern Baptists are being required to share a single viewpoint of their faith. It's ``like you used to have in factories that stamped out records _ same speeds, same size, same song,'' Honeycutt said. The 44-year-old news service, considered one of the nation's most open and objective denominational news agencies, serves 400 outlets, including 38 independent Baptist state weeklies. It maintains bureaus in Dallas; Washington, D.C.; Atlanta; and Richmond, Va. The Rev. Rick Cagle, an executive committee member from Gadsden, Ala., said the resignation order came because some Baptist journalists were letting their politics show. ``You've got a lot of churches who don't even send the Baptist publications out to their members because they feel they're so biased,'' Cagle said. The Rev. J.B. Fowler, who heads the Southern Baptist Press Association, disagreed. He accused conservatives of trying to neutralize ideological opponents. ``In any takeover attempt, regardless of what it is or who it is, one of the things taken over is the press, that it might be silenced,'' said Fowler, editor of the Baptist New Mexican, one of the 38 state Baptist papers. Shackleford said the struggle is as simple, and important, as free speech. ``We are basically asking for a right to focus on the real issue, and that is the Baptist right to know,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Palestinian Terrorist Living in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: A West Berlin newspaper said Sunday that a terrorist suspected of involvement in the 1972 Munich Olympics massacre of Israeli athletes is living in East Germany. The Berliner Morgenpost said the internationally sought terrorist, known as Abu Daoud, had lived in the East Berlin Palast Hotel for several years until mid-1988. The report said he is still believed to be somewhere in East Berlin. An East German Interior Ministry spokesman said Sunday his office was investigating the report, but had no other comment. East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel has been quoted as saying the former secret police, known as Stasi, sheltered the international terrorist Carlos as well as one of the men believed responsible for the Sept. 5, 1972, attack at the Munich Olympics that left 11 Israeli athletes dead. The now-disbanded Stasi has also been accused of harboring West German Red Army Faction terrorists and having contacts with Libyan, Basque separatist and Irish Republican Army terrorists. Abu Daoud, whose real name is Mahmoud Daoud, was a senior officer of Fatah, the faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization led by PLO chief Yasser Arafat. Daoud was among the Fatah personalities believed to have had a hand in the Black September terrorist group that carried out some of the most notorious attacks of the 1970s, including the massacre at the Munich Olympics. Daoud reportedly survived an assassination attempt in Warsaw in 1981. The newspaper said two of its reporters had ``followed Abu Daoud's trail in the Palast Hotel.'' The paper said he stayed there under the name ``Tarek'' four to five times a year in a two-room apartment on the eighth floor that was equipped with a large bed, color television and a bar. The room cost $175 a night and the newspaper said he was treated as a VIP guest of the hotel. The newspaper based its information on interviews with several hotel workers and said many had recognized a photograph of the suspected terrorist which the reporters had brought with them. Employees learned of the man's real identity in 1986 from the hotel management and were ordered to keep silent, the newspaper added. One hotel chambermaid, who was not named, said the man in question slept with ``a big caliber revolver'' under his pillow, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Said to Warn of Bomb Threat Against Pan Am
DOC.TEXT: A London newspaper reported Sunday that U.S. authorities have warned U.S. airlines of a threat to blow up a Pan Am jet on a flight from West Germany in the next 10 days. In Washington, FAA spokesman Fred Farrar refused to comment Sunday. In New York, Pan Am spokesman Jeff Kreindler also declined comment and referred all queries to the FAA. The Sunday Correspondent quoted a confidential Federal Aviation Adminstration bulletin as saying: ``A female student with a Canadian passport may be duped into carrying a suitcase containing a bomb on to a Pan Am flight from either Frankfurt or Berlin.'' The FAA issues hundreds of bomb threat warnings to airlines each year, and the newspaper quoted the bulletin as saying ``there are doubts about the reliability of the individual that originated the threat information.'' It said the bulletin was issued Tuesday to all U.S. airlines and selected airports. It quoted the bulletin as saying the student was reportedly studying at the Sorbonne in Paris and is now touring Europe. Her destination and date of departure are unknown, it said. The student ``allegedly has a Middle Eastern boyfriend'' who will give her a suitcase containing a bomb made of the Semtex plastic explosive, the newspaper was quoted as saying. It did not say how it obtained its information. A bomb concealed in a radio-cassette recorder blew up a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988, killing all 259 people on board and 11 on the ground. The New York-bound flight originated in Frankfurt and changed aircraft in London. After the crash, it emerged that the FAA had issued a bomb warning to airlines and diplomats. The Sunday Correspondent said American intelligence experts believe the source of the latest warning could have been the Israeli intelligence agency, the Mossad. It said they suspect the Mossad is attempting to disrupt the release of Irish teacher Brian Keenan, who has been a captive in Lebanon since April 1986. The paper said the Mossad was also the source of a warning that preceded the Lockerbie bomb plot. It said that warning was dismissed as an Israeli attempt to interfere with PLO leader Yasser Arafat's overtures to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Prime Minister Withdraws His Resignation
LaserPhoto DEL6
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh withdrew his resignation offer Sunday, but the dispute within the coalition government that caused the crisis remained unresolved and four more ministers reportedly quit. ``For the sake of the nation, its unity and sovereignty, we asked (Singh) to withdraw his resignation, which he agreed to do,'' said N.T. Rama Rao, the chairman of the governing National Front alliance. Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral and three other ministers resigned Sunday, United News of India said. The latest resignations brought to 13 the number of ministers who have quit the government in the dispute. Rao made the announcement about Singh after a 90-minute meeting between National Front leaders and the prime minister. The front is composed of Singh's Janata Dal Party and four smaller groups. However, Janata Dal President Somappa Rayappa Bommai said the two-day-old crisis gripping the minority government continues. ``The crisis is not over yet. I am in the process of getting to a solution,'' Bommai told a news conference. He refused to elaborate. Singh's offer of resignation was prompted by a power struggle with Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, who has been promoting his son's political career despite growing protests and outrage from senior Janata Dal members. Rao said Singh was persuaded to remain in office because ``the prime minister does not belong to one party, he belongs to the National Front. He has a commitment to the National Front and to the nation.'' Rao and other national leaders of the front arrived in New Delhi Sunday after local leaders failed a day earlier to force Singh to retract his resignation. Singh submitted his resignation Saturday to Bommai. Bommai rejected the offer, but Singh had remained adamant until the front leaders met with him. The 7-month-old government was pushed into disarray Friday when three Cabinet ministers resigned to protest the restoration of Devi Lal's son to the top government job in Haryana state. Six more ministers resigned Saturday. Bommai said the nine ministers' resignations were still in effect and the issue was not discussed at Sunday's meeting with Singh. The party's efforts to retain Singh as prime minister reinforced the view that the prime minister was not serious about resigning and was trying to force a showdown with Devi Lal, the biggest irritant in Singh's control of the government. The government had bogged down while Singh tried to cope with Devi Lal's pressure tactics and tackle the business of running the country. The crisis was precipitated when Devi Lal, the 75-year-old political patriarch of Haryana state, reinstated his son, Om Prakash Chautala, as head of the state government. Chautala was forced from the chief minister's office in May after 12 people died in repeated election violence in his constituency. Chautala took his oath of office Thursday, and the next day three members of the national Cabinet resigned in protest. On Saturday, Singh himself offered to resign and six more junior ministers followed suit. Bommai and Rao evaded questions about Chautala's fate. Rao, leader of the Telegu Desam party, said it was up to the Janata Dal to resolve the crisis. Singh led his party in ousting Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party in last November's national elections. Neither party got a majority of the seats in Parliament, but the National Front formed the government on the strength of outside support by a right-wing Hindu fundamentalist party and left-wing parties. The common ground of the three groups was their antipathy to the Congress Party.

DOC.HEAD: Deaths of Gray Whales Stump Scientists
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-three gray whale carcasses have washed up on two remote islands south of Kodiak, and scientists planned a study to determine why the mammals died. ``The concern is that we have a bunch of dead whales and we don't know the cause,'' said Steve Zimmerman, chief of the protected resources management division of the National Marine Fisheries Service in Juneau. National Marine Fisheries Service officials in a U.S. Coast Guard helicopter flew to the beaches in the Gulf of Alaska on Saturday and planned to examine the dead whales for two days. They circled Tugidak and Sitkinak islands in the air to determine how many carcasses were there and spotted 14 whales on Tugidak and nine on Sitkinak. The 23 are the largest number of dead grays ever discovered in the gulf, said Zimmerman, whose agency is mandated by Congress to protect the whales and monitor their population. Effects of last year's Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound were among possible reasons for the deaths, but Zimmerman said that was unlikely. The gulf is on the migration path of the whales, which travel from Baja California to the Bering Sea every March. The gray whale population is booming. More than 20,000 of the mammals were estimated to have migrated this year from their warm Mexican lagoons to feeding grounds in icy Alaska waters. Twenty-three carcasses is ``a large number of dead whales, certainly,'' said Don Calkins, a wildlife biologist with the Alaska Department of Fish and Game. ``But the way the gray whale population is going, it may not be that significant.'' In fact, the burgeoning population may play a part in the deaths, authorities said. ``It appears to be an indication of population stress,'' said Jim Brooks, a fisheries service deputy director in Juneau. Brooks said the whales' behavior lately has been odd. For instance, they've been seen in places far off their migration path _ including in the waters near Juneau, hundreds of miles east. ``If you get enough people or animals of any sorts, you're going to get misfits,'' Brooks said. The gray whales range from 36 to 50 feet long and are relatively thin when they arrive at Alaska waters. They are known to eat very little for the six months they remain at Baja California. The Bering Sea, the vast body of water separating Alaska's west coast from the Soviet Union, provides the whales with an ocean-bottom food supply of crustaceans. Authorities said carcasses found near Kodiak may be the remains of weak animals unable to continue the journey north. Strong currents in the region could have washed the whales ashore, scientist speculated.

DOC.HEAD: Islamic Councils Ban Popular Music, Segregate Schools
DOC.TEXT: Local Islamic fundamentalist councils have banned a form of popular music and forbidden girls and boys from sharing the same schoolrooms, the Algerian media reported. Along the Mediterranean coast west of the capital, where fundamentalists won stunning victories in local and regional elections last month, ``rai'' music is now banned. The music, a sort of Arabic rock celebrating love, sex and youthful revolt, fails to ``correspond to the morals and precepts of Islam,'' local media reported Saturday. Authorities are apparently searching for another form of entertainment. They organized a three-day festival last week in Oran dedicated to ``Islamic patriotic songs.'' The provincial council of Constantine, in eastern Algeria, meanwhile has ruled out mixed classrooms in schools and universities. The An Nasr newspaper said the council, under the control of the Islamic Salvation Front, has also banned the sale of all alcoholic beverages in the province. Bars will be shut down and the distribution of non-alcholic beverages reorganized in an unspecified manner, An Nasr said. Similar measures have already been taken in several of the constituencies won by the front in Algeria's first contested elections since independence from France in 1962. The fundamentalists trounced the ruling National Liberation Front in the balloting, winning 835 of 1,539 municipalities and 32 of the 48 provincial councils. Islamic Salvation Front officials in the seaside resort of Tipaza last week banned nudity and modern bathing suits on local beaches. Short pants can be no shorter than the top of the knee for men and the botton of the knee for women.

DOC.HEAD: Politician Suggests Arming Palestinians Who Support Israel
DOC.TEXT: An extreme right-wing member of the governing coalition said Sunday that Palestinians who support Israel should be armed and organized to patrol the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Also Sunday, a Palestinian suspected of cooperating with Israeli authorities was found hanged to death in the West Bank town of Nablus, Arab reports said. Police said they were investigating the death. The death raises to 236 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the 31-month-old uprising against Israeli rule. Most were suspected of cooperating with Israeli authorities. A total of 723 Palestinians have died of Israeli gunfire during the rebellion, and 45 Israelis have been slain in the violence. Eliakim Haetzni of the nationalist Tehiya party said in an interview Sunday that Palestinians should be organized into units whose duty would be to ``enforce order'' in Palestinian villages in the occupied lands. ``We should give them automatic weapons, police uniforms and radios and let them institute the law,'' said Haetzni, a Jewish settler who lives in the West Bank. Israel has issued weapons to some Palestinians who work with the authorities, but only for the purposes of self-defense. Haetzni said his proposal was submitted to the Defense Ministry in the past weeks. Defense Ministry spokeman Dan Naveh said he had not yet seen the proposal, ``but we take any proposals by a member of the ruling coalition seriously,'' he added. Senior security officials, however, dismissed the idea and said it was not being discussed in the Defense Ministry. Yossi Sarid, of the left-wing opposition Citizens Rights Movement, termed the plan ``lunatic, the work of a fringe character.''

DOC.HEAD: China, Soviet Union to Set Up Their First Joint Venture in China
DOC.TEXT: An agreement to set up the first Sino-Soviet joint venture in China is expected to be signed within two months, an official report said Sunday. The two countries already have about 20 joint ventures, mostly restaurants, in the Soviet Union. But the planned flax textile firm in Inner Mongolia would be the first in China, the English-language Business Weekly said. The flax mill in Baotou, 155 miles south of the Soviet border, is expected to be completed in 1992, according to Ji Jun of the Textile Ministry. Ji said construction had already begun. The Chinese side will handle capital construction while four Soviet firms are to supply spinning machines and materials. The report did not say how much each side would invest or how the ownership will be divided. In the 1950s, the Soviet Union sent thousands of technical advisers to help develop China. That cooperation ended when the two Communist powers split over ideological and other differences at the end of the decade. Relations have warmed in recent years, and diplomatic ties were normalized last year when Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev visited Beijing for the first summit in 30 years. Trade has developed correspondingly. Last year's trade volume was estimated at $3.2 billion, or more than 14 times that of 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Church Denounces Government Coverup of Jesuit Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Declaring the country ``a kingdom of lies,'' a leading Roman Catholic clergyman Sunday accused the military of hindering an inquiry into the massacre of six Jesuit priests. ``We hope all those involved will be prosecuted,'' said Monsignor Ricardo Urioste. ``The sad thing is that in this case, it seems there is a truth we already know, but there are those who have an interest in preventing that truth from being demonstrated. ...'' ``We live in a kingdom of lies, and such a kingdom will destroy itself,'' Urioste said in remarks to journalists. Earlier, Urioste delivered the nationally broadcast weekly sermon in place of Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas, who is out of the country. Urioste is vicar of the capital's archdiocese. He told journalists he believed military officers questioned in connection with last year's massacre had lied to Judge Ricardo Zamora. Army troops killed the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter before dawn on Nov. 16. A colonel, three lieutenants and five other soldiers have been charged with the murders. The far-right had long considered the priests to be subversives. It accused them of sympathizing with leftist guerrillas waging a decade-old insurgency. At least 70,000 people, mostly civilians have died in that civil war. The military has repeatedly pledged complete cooperation with the investigation. But despite the promises, military authorities have not handed over to Zamora a lieutenant colonel accused of ordering the destruction of possibly key evidence. On June 26, Zamora ordered the arrest of Lt. Col. Camilo Hernandez on charges of covering up the murder. The joint chiefs of staff said Hernandez was placed under arrest July 5. However, he has yet to be taken before a judge. ``This is another demonstration that there are those who seem to be above the law,'' Urioste said. The massacre had prompted calls in the U.S. Congress for cuts in aid to El Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: Much of Nation Cool From Florida to Nebraska; Flooding in Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably cool weather speckled the nation from Florida to Nebraska on Sunday, and heavy rains and flooding pounded parts of Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Ohio, and sections of the Southeast. Parts of Crawford and Venengo counties in northwest Pennsylvania were flooded, including two feet of water in streets in Titusville. Flooding extended into the West Virginia Panhandle, where a mudslides were reported in Brooke County and Route 2 was flooded near Wellsburg. Many creeks were out of their banks and roadway flooding was reported in Hancock County. Evacuations were prompted in Ohio, but those orders were later lifted. Still, an offramp from Interstate 80 was closed by high water near Hubbard, Ohio, and a bridge at the town was washed out. State roads also were closed by flooding at Boardman and Lowellville. There was local flooding in Illinois from heavy rain at La Salle, Marseilles and Ottawa. San Angelo, Texas, also reported extensive street flooding Sunday. Heavier rainfalls during the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included two inches at San Angelo, Texas and an inch at Tucson, Ariz. Flooding in Arizona was reported at Tucson, Maricopa, Casa Grande and Coolidge.More than two inches of rain caused extensive flooding in the business district of Florence. On Sunday, showers and thunderstorms extended from western New York state across much of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, Virginia, West Virginia, eastern Ohio and southeast lower Michigan. Showers and storms also reached from eastern North Carolina across the South Carolina coast, over much of the Florida peninsula, across a large part of Texas and western Oklahoma; from northern Illinois across Wisconsin into western Upper Michigan; in southeast Iowa, northwest Minnesota, southwestern South Dakota, and central and southern Arizona; and central California. Several cities set record lows for the date on Sunday. Among them were Evansville, Ind., 52; Goodland, Kan., 52; Grand Island, Neb., 52; Hot Springs, Ark., 52; Lincoln, Neb., 51; Paducah Ky., 55; and Wichita, Kan., 55. Hollywood, Fla., tied its record low for the date, 69 degrees, set in 1980. Low temperature for the nation Sunday morning was 39 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 58 degrees at Crescent City, Calif., to 98 at Palm Springs and Redding, both in California.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Refugee Ferry Arrives in French Harbor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with details, color from arrival; quotes from refugees; report of demonstration by refugees arriving in Turkey. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Albanian refugees sang the French national anthem to celebrate their newfound freedom as they arrived at this port city Sunday after a three-day journey from their Communist homeland. ``Long live France! Long live the Albanian people!'' the refugees chanted as they left the ferry Orient Star on Marseille's docks. The new arrivals are the last of thousands who boarded five ferries last week for Western Europe. The Albanians had sought refuge from the hard-line Communist regime in their homeland by fleeing to Western embassies in Tirana, the Albanian capital. President Ramiz Alia's regime, the last bastion of orthodox Communism in Eastern Europe, allowed the refugees to leave. Hundreds of ethnic Albanians living in France and Belgium lined the docks of Marseille Sunday to welcome the refugees, singing the traditional Albanian national anthem, ``Around the Flag,'' as the ferry pulled into port. ``For me, this is a new birth,'' said Albert Aziri, an ethnic Albanian from Yugoslavia who came to France in 1953. ``I'm going to see my people, people who have the same blood as me.'' About 100 Red Cross doctors, nurses and other workers took charge of the 544 refugees, including 63 children, after they left the ferry to begin a new life. Asked what was wrong with his homeland, one of the refugees, Arian Cipa, replied simply: ``No freedom. No money. No future.'' ``I know it won't be easy for me in France, but I hope to succeed. I won't go back to Albania until the Communists are gone,'' said Cipa, a geological engineer. Cipa was among those who took refuge in the French Embassy in Tirana, the Albanian capital, for eight days before a U.N.-mediated settlement allowed thousands of Albanians in foreign embassies to leave for the West. Few of the refugees carried substantial luggage. Many wore only plain T-shirts, poorly fitting trousers and sandals. Bernard Kouchner, secretary of state for humanitarian action, escorted the Albanians to special trains bound for three reception centers near Paris and one in southwestern France. At the centers, fresh clothes, soap and toothpaste await the refugees. They will be given medical examinations, French lessons and instruction in the basics of the French social security system. The refugees also will be given temporary residence permits and have the right to apply for political asylum. A 25-year-old refugee who identified himself only as Afrim said Albanian authorities had prevented his wife and young son from boarding the Orient Star. ``I hope there won't be any reprisals against them,'' he said, expressing hope they would be allowed to join him in France. The ferry had originally been scheduled to arrive on Saturday, coinciding with celebrations of Bastille Day, the national holiday marking the start of the French revolution against tyranny. The arrival was delayed after a 21-year-old pregnant woman had to be taken off the ship in Italy with an unspecified ailment. Many of the expatriate Albanians on the docks Sunday back the pretender to Albania's throne, Leka I. Red flags bearing the double-headed eagle of the monarchy, deposed in 1939 by an Italian invasion, fluttered under blazing summer skies until a French official ordered them taken down. Francois Filliatre, the port's assistant prefect, told the monarchists to take down the flags half an hour before the ship arrived. His assistants distributed French flags. ``It's France who welcomes them and only the French flag should be present,'' Filliatre told an aide to Leka, Hylle Spahija. The monarchists grumbled but complied. Riot police prevented the ethnic Albanians from embracing the new arrivals. Only a few expatriates who spoke good French were able to talk their way past the police cordon to greet the refugees. Earlier Sunday, another 76 Albanians flashed the ``V'' for victory sign when they arrived in Turkey on a government-sponsored flight from Tirana. Some of the refugees arriving in Turkey said they had heard reports that about 6,000 people staged a pro-democracy demonstration in the northern Albanian city of Shkoder on Friday, and seven protesters were killed in a clash with soldiers. The report could not be independently confirmed. About 4,500 Albanians were evacuated in a boatlift across the Adriatic Sea to Brindisi, Italy, on Friday. Some remained in Italy, and 544 traveled on the French-chartered Yugoslav ferry Orient Star to Marseille. More than 3,000 of the Albanians who had sought refuge in the West German Embassy traveled by train to West Germany. It was unclear how many wanted to stay in West Germany or eventually go to the United States or other countries. Also Saturday, 56 Albanians from the Polish Embassy in Tirana were flown to Warsaw. Another 39 who sought refuge in the Hungarian Embassy were flown to Budapest. Five others from the Bulgarian Embassy traveled to Sofia. On Saturday night, two Albanians fled to Yugoslavia, raising to 15 the number of Albanians who have illegally crossed the Yugoslav border in the past week, the state Tanjug news agency reported. The refugees began crowding into the embassies in Tirana two weeks ago, seeking to flee Albania, which has resisted the kinds of sweeping democratic reforms that have radically altered other East European countries. Refugees said Albanians rushed the embassies after hearing that a family that had been in the Italian Embassy since 1985 was leaving the country.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Throws a Party for Jurors who Acquitted Her
With AM-Marcos
DOC.TEXT: After weeks of testimony about how she and her late husband stole millions to buy skyscrapers and jewelry, Imelda Marcos thought the jurors who acquitted her deserved to be shown some appreciation. Drawing on her experience as the first lady in Manila, she threw a party. It featured Filipino food and entertainment, including Mrs. Marcos' own soprano rendering of ``God Bless America.'' Ten of the 12 jurors who on July 2 acquitted Mrs. Marcos and her co-defendant, Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, attended the Saturday afternoon affair at Mrs. Marcos' penthouse on Manhattan's East Side. The 100-plus guests also included court personnel, and friends and relatives who had sat every day in the courtroom, lending moral support to Mrs. Marcos as the government tried to prove her and Khashoggi guilty of fraud and obstructing justice. Khashoggi stayed only briefly. He said he was flying later to Saudi Arabia to make a long delayed visit to Islam's holy shrines in Mecca. Since the trial, several jurors have said they felt the government's case was confused and failed to show that Mrs. Marcos had direct knowledge of the financial dealings of her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos. They also have said they doubted some key witnesses who claimed Khashoggi had falsified documents to help the Marcoses conceal their ownership of four New York buildings and artwork bought with the allegedly stolen money. Some of the jurors brought family members to the party. ``It's just a gathering of friends,'' said ex-juror Luellen White, a subway worker who left carrying a decorated cake. Others departed with bouquets of flowers. Mrs. Marcos said during the party that she has been ordered by the U.S. Justice Department to face grand jury questioning in another criminal proceeding, one involving a lawsuit by the current Philippines government against Westinghouse Electric Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Rock Pakistani City, Killing 43
DOC.TEXT: Seven bombs exploded in this ethnically troubled city Sunday, killing at least 43 people and injuring scores, officials said. Six of the blasts occurred within 10 minutes of each other in different areas of the city, police said. Those bombs killed 33 people and injured 110, hospital officials said. The explosives were placed at residential areas, a market and a bus stop. Hospital officials said they feared the death toll would rise. Pakistan's state-run news agency, however, said only 12 people died in the six bombings. The discrepancy in the casualties was not immediately explained, but the state-run news agency, Associated Press of Pakistan, usually reports a lower death toll than hospital and police sources. Meanwhile, about an hour later, a seventh bomb ripped through the second-class coach of a southbound train minutes after it left Hyderabad, the news agency said. It reported 10 dead and 15 injured in that bombing. No one claimed responsibility for the bombings, but police said they suspected Sindh nationalists demanding greater autonomy from Pakistan. The Sindh nationalists, who control most of the countryside, regularly clash with members of the Mohajir Qami Movement, which represents Indian immigrants who came to Pakistan following partition of the subcontinent in 1947. The Mohajirs want to be recognized as a fifth ethnic nationality. Sindh nationalists had called a one-day strike Sunday to protest the arrest several weeks ago of Qada Magsi, a Sindhi activist, charged with inciting violence. Most rival Mohajirs, who control Hyderabad, a bitterly divided city of 3 million, refused to honor the strike call. Police speculated the refusal prompted the bombings. Meanwhile, witnesses in Hyderabad said troops opened fire on mourners who had gathered outside a local hospital, where many of the dead were taken. Three people were killed in the firing, according to several witness accounts. Other witnesses reported snipers in vehicles opened fire on panicked crowds fleeing the bomb sites. In the past two months, hundreds of people have been killed in Hyderabad and Pakistan's southern port city of Karachi, 100 miles south. The deaths have been blamed on bitter ethnic rivalry between Sindh nationalists and the Indian immigrants. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto earlier acknowledged the Sindh state government headed by her Pakistan's People's Party has not done enough to stop the rising violence in her home province. The Mohajir Movement broke ranks with Ms. Bhutto in November, claiming her populist Pakistan People's Party backed off promises. The movement, which controls 14 seats in the National Assembly, aligned itself with Ms. Bhutto's opposition. The move prompted a no-confidence vote, which she narrowly survived. On May 27 after weeks of killings, Ms. Bhutto deployed the army in both Hyderabad and Karachi. Thousands of police and soldiers now patrol the cities. But the army has also become openly critical of Ms. Bhutto, claiming she has done little to defuse tensions and open talks. Some quarters of the military reportedly want greater powers in Sindh, something Ms. Bhutto has resisted.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Approves New Housing Plan For Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: The government Sunday approved an emergency plan to house thousands of Soviet immigrants in hotels, youth hostels and sanitariums. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, chairman of the government's immigration committee, said the new plan would ease Israel's housing crisis. ``I brought this proposal ... in order to block the skyrocketing housing prices and to stop the young couples, Israelis, from being thrown out of the apartments they live in,'' Sharon said on army radio. The plan was approved Sunday by the immigration committee, which is composed of representatives from different ministries dealing with immigration. Rents have doubled and in some cases tripled with the arrival of a huge wave of Soviet immigrants. Since 1986, about 63,000 Soviet Jews have arrived in Israel. That figure is expected to hit 150,000 by the end of this year. Many Israelis have been forced out of homes or apartments they rent by inflated housing prices. Some have taken to living in tents to dramatize their plight. According to government figures, the country's 20,000 available rental apartments will be filled by the end of September. Absorption Ministry spokeswoman Ida Ben-Shitrit said under the new plan immigrants will be offered a choice of living in apartments, low-rate hotels or youth hostels. ``This emergency plan will be implemented as an alternative route, according to the choice of the immigrant,'' she said. She said low-rate hotels and youth hostels had the potential of housing a maximum of 60,000 immigrants.

DOC.HEAD: Chilean Navy Fires On Soviet Trawler
DOC.TEXT: A navy patrol boat fired on a Soviet trawler after it entered territorial waters and ignored orders to halt, a navy communique said. There was no word on injuries or damage to the vessel, which fled. According to the communique, the incident occurred early Saturday in the Pacific Ocean about 180 miles off the southern coast. The text of the communique, issued later Saturday, was carried by Santiago newspapers on Sunday. It said a navy patrol boat spotted the trawler, identified as the Odishi, at 3 a.m. and ordered it by radio and lantern to stop and let authorities board. ``As it didn't obey the patrol's orders, we proceeded to fire successive warning shots,'' the communique said. ``It still didn't halt, so we fired on its superstructure.'' The government secretary-general, Enrique Correa, said the navy kept the government informed during the incident. He said the navy acted in accordance with international law.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 1,200 Need Medical Help During Bastille Event
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,200 people needed treatment for injuries and other medical problems after taking to the streets for a sound-and-light extravaganza capping Bastille Day, the Red Cross said Sunday. About 2 million participants packed the banks of the Seine River and avenues leading to the financial-district suburb of La Defense to watch the mammoth concent by Jean-Michel Jarre on Saturday night. The Red Cross said Sunday that 22 of the revelers were hospitalized for injuries. It gave no details of their injuries. Another 1,200 spectators sought relief at first-aid stations, the agency said in a communique. It said most of those seeking first aid were in need of water, sugar or rest. The show capped daylong festivities featuring a military parade and a pledge by President Francois Mitterrand to keep French nuclear and conventional forces independent and strong. The holiday celebrates the fall of the Bastille prison in 1789 that marked the beginning of the French Revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Military Brass Downplay Panama Invasion Re-enactment in Air Show
LaserPhoto SE2
DOC.TEXT: About 125,000 people attended an air show billed as a re-enactment of the invasion of Panama, but the military, stung by criticism of insensitivity, downplayed the event. The early press release for the base's 50th anniversary celebration promised a ``re-enactment of the invasion of Panama, with the actual aircraft, air crews and soldiers who were there participating!'' But Capt. John Litton denied Saturday's event was a re-enactment. ``That was just something that got overemphasized in a news release,'' he said. Still, many of those who oohed and aahed the air show aerobatics at the oldest Air Force base in the Pacific Northwest said they were drawn by word they would get some of the sound and fury of the Dec. 20 invasion. ``I think it's appropriate for them to re-create the Panama invasion,'' said Jean Smith, a Tacoma grandmother joined by three of her 18 grandchildren. ``This way you get a chance to find out exactly what goes on, to see it for yourself.'' ``War is war, and that's a fact of life,'' said Henry Stahl, who brought his son, a member of the Air Force ROTC, to the show. ``If the military does a good job, I think they should let the people see.'' Fighter planes roared overhead at 600 mph, and bombers and helicopters swooped low on mock strafing runs. Paratroopers bailed out of a C-141. The show did include some troops who participated in the Panama invasion, said Bob Rosenburgh, a civilian Fort Lewis spokesman. Officials said they received some criticism and accusations of an insensitivity to the loss of life in the invasion and overthrow of Gen. Manuel Noriega. ``Somebody on base overhyped the event,'' insisted Col. Mike McCarthy, base commander. ``As soon as I heard about it, I said, `It's a mistake. We're not doing Panama II.''' ``We got a lot of flak about it,'' said Sgt. Randy Mitchell. ``It doesn't make sense to me. The public was overwhelmingly behind the (Panama) operation, but now it's a sensitive subject, like Vietnam.'' Thousands of U.S. combat troops raided Panama in December to oust and arrest Noriega and install as president Guillermo Endara, who had lost May elections that were widely described as fraudulent. The invasion ultimately cost the lives of 220 civilians and at least 300 soldiers, 23 of whom were American, according to the Pentagon.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather to Protest Communist Party Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf `A police...' to fix typos in crowd estimates to read 50,000 and 400,000. Pickup 8th graf pvs `The rain ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB9
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people marched to the Kremlin walls on Sunday to protest Communist Party control of the government, the army and the KGB and to demand greater democracy in the Soviet Union. The protest came just two days after the party concluded a historic congress in which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev consolidated his control of the center but lost some of the party's best-known radical reformers, who quit. The march took place despite a nearly constant rain. The slogans were graphic: ``Communist worms _ this corpse won't feed you anymore,'' said one poster. A woman hoisted a pair of shoes worn into tatters and labeled, ``Slave of the Party.'' Another banner said: ``Communist Party Onto the Trash Heap of History.'' ``Every Communist to his own mausoleum!'' read one poster, a reference to the mausoleum of Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin just a few hundred yards away. Many Soviet citizens still treat Lenin as a veritable God, and thousands file through his crypt every day to pay homage to his mummified body. The protesters, huddled under a sea of umbrellas, hoisted sodden red-white-and-blue flags of pre-revolutionary Russia and the black flag of anarchist groups. Police used trucks to block entrances to Red Square, and the protesters ended their march in adjacent Manezh square along one wall of the Kremlin fortress. A police officer and local television station estimated the crowd at 50,000, while an organizer announced that 400,000 people marched. Western correspondents estimated the crowd at between 40,000 and 100,000. The rain apparently kept the size of the crowd down, although the rally had been advertised in Moscow newspapers and on radio stations. In an announcement Saturday, the Evening Moscow newspaper said the rally ``was expected to be the largest joint action of democratic forces of Moscow since Feb. 25.'' On that date, a crowd estimated at between 100,000 and 500,000 marched to demand democratic reform. On Feb. 4, about 200,000 demonstrators demanded an end to the Communist Party's monopoly on power. But Sunday's protest marked the first time a large crowd had demonstrated such clear sentiments denouncing the entire Communist system. The crowd cheered and waved their banners when a speaker mentioned the names of reformers who quit the party last week: Russian Federation President Boris Yeltsin, Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov and Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak. The protesters raised their hands at the end of the rally to show their approval of a resolution calling for all ``aware'' Communists to quit the party, which now claims 19 million members. People poured in from side streets as the marchers passed along the rain-swept Krimsky Bridge over the Moscow River and through the Garden Ring Road, closed to traffic by police. One woman wore a wooden toilet seat around her neck, and labeled it ``Polozkov'' after Ivan Polozkov, the hard-line leader of the Communist Party in the Russian republic. Organizers of the march included the Moscow Voters' Club, the radical reform groups Democratic Platform and Democratic Russia, and an organization of reform-minded police and military officers named Shield. In leaflets announcing the rally, they had called for the Communists to disband their party cells in the army and KGB, and to accept a coalition government. That echoes the calls of reformers who Thursday announced at the congress they were quitting the Communist Party. Yeltsin has wide support among the nation's working class, especially the restive miners. Democratic Platform leader Vladimir Lysenko said Soviet coal miners, who staged a one-day strike last week to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, called for a second strike in September. That strike would continue until the prime minister steps down, he said. The crowd broke into shouts of ``Resign! Resign!'' and shook their fists. At the end of the congress, the party announced a new structure for its ruling Politburo that will no longer include such government officials as the prime minister, the foreign minister, the KGB chief and the defense minister. But radical reformers say that does not touch the foundation of Communist Party power in the Soviet Union. Several pro-Yeltsin banners were visible in the crowd. One marcher advised Gorbachev to give up on his comrades in the party, and expressed her support for Yeltsin. Gorbachev ``has done all he could do with the party,'' said Anna Balykova, a woman in her 40s who came to the protest with her son. ``He has no more possibilities.'' Of Yeltsin, she said, ``I pin all my hopes on him.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Members of British Party Try to Resurrect Dissolved Group
DOC.TEXT:
A faction of the Social Democratic Party, a centrist group whose dissolution was announced last month, said Sunday they won't let their party die. Members who are seeking to keep the 9-year-old party alive said they had overturned last month's decision by founder David Owen and other party leaders to dissolve the Social Democrats. Members of the party's national committee who refused to accept the dissolution said they took legal advice and decided that the disbandment violated the party's constitution. ``We have formally rescinded the decision, and the party again exists,'' said John Martin, a member of the national committee. However, it was not clear how much support his faction could muster to keep the party alive. The party's national committee had voted 17-5 on June 3 to suspend its constitution and disband. At the time, Owen cited the party's declining membership, which had collapsed to 6,200 from a peak of 68,000 soon after the Social Democrats were founded in January 1981. Owen is one of only three legislators the party has in the 650-member House of Commons. The three will continue to hold their seats as independent Social Democrats. Owen's decision to pull out was seen as the end of the party. But Martin said he would ask the party's parliamentary candidates to remain on board to prepare for the next election, which must be held by mid-1992. Owen and three other former Cabinet ministers broke with the Labor Party in 1981 to offer voters a centrist alternative to the Conservative Party and then-increasingly leftist Laborites. The Social Democrats had hoped to supplant Labor as the main challenger to the Conservatives, who are led by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. But Labor, led by Neil Kinnock, has abandoned its support for unilateral nuclear disarmament and unveiled a more centrist platform this year. Recent polls show it leads the Conservatives.
The Social Democrats enjoyed their biggest electoral success when they joined with the longer-established Liberals under the name Alliance. That group polled 26 percent of the national vote in the 1983 general election and 22.6 percent in 1987. But because of Britain's winner-take-all electoral system, it never won more than a handful of parliamentary seats. After winning only 22 of the 650 parliamentary districts in 1987, a majority of the membership of the two parties agreed to merge as the Social and Liberal Democrats. Owen and loyal supporters opposed to the merger, remaining Social Democrats. Last month, Owen said he had no plans for now to rejoin the Labor Party. He served as foreign minister from 1977-79 under a Labor government and was once seen as a potential prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: Child Waiting with Family Drowns Outside Hospital
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old who strayed from his father drowned in a pond 50 feet from a hospital where his mother was comforting a sick baby sister, police said. The body of Darren Shiwcharan was pulled from the pond in front of Centurion Hospitals of Carrollwood by Hillsborough County sheriff's divers Saturday morning, said sheriff's spokesman Jack Espinosa. The boy apparently drowned in the 5-foot-deep pond while his father and another sister dozed inside the family's station wagon in a parking lot, Espinosa said. ``My eyes just closed a second, and the next thing I know he was gone,'' said the father, Sewdat Shiwcharan, 39. ``I thought he had fallen asleep. I ran to the emergency room, but he wasn't there.'' The Shiwcharans brought their 6-month-old daughter to the hospital Friday night because she had a high fever. ``We had to wait for 45 minutes, and there wasn't anybody else there they were working on,'' he said. ``Finally they took her and my wife into the emergency room. ``(Darren) was crying because he wanted to be with his mother. I told them that. They got a security guard and ... kicked us out.'' But hospital officials said the father was asked to stay in a waiting room only after he verbally abused the emergency staff. A security guard was called to the waiting room to watch the father, who then went to his car with his son and 8-year-old daughter, said hospital administrator Bill Chambers. Chambers said Shiwcharan was ``very upset about something. Foul language was being used by him in the emergency room.'' The three went to the car about 1 a.m. Darren apparently got out at about about 20 minutes later, Chambers said. A couple leaving the hospital at the time said later that they saw the boy heading toward nearby Dale Mabry Highway. A search of the hospital and its grounds began when the father discovered the boy missing. It ended just before daybreak when divers found the boy's body. The parents are natives of Guyana and moved to Tampa two years ago so the husband could take a job as a mechanic. ``If they had allowed the kids to go in the hospital and stay with me, this would not have happened,'' said the mother, Sabitree Shiwcharan, 29. Chambers disagreed. ``We were taking care of who we were supposed to be taking care of _ the baby girl,'' he said. The infant was treated and released.

DOC.HEAD: Parade Threatened with Violence Goes off Without a Hitch
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people flocked to downtown Milwaukee Sunday to enjoy the annual Great Circus Parade despite threats by a radical alderman who had planned a demonstration to protest inner-city problems. Alderman Michael McGee, who has organized a black militia and threatened violence in coming years if better jobs and housing are not provided for his constitutents, told parade sponsors last week that children should stay away from the parade because matters ``could get ugly.'' But faced with a court restraining order, McGee called off the threat and there were no protests at the parade, which took place under overcast skies and occasional drizzle. Still, ``you couldn't help but be nervous and think about it,'' said Jeff Evans, of Waukesha. ``It's too bad that people were stirring up all this trouble.'' The parade included elephants and other circus animals. Actor Ernest Borgnine was one of the costumed clowns. It also featured about 75 brightly painted, carved wooden wagons from the State Historical Society's museum collection. The wagons are hauled annually by train to Milwaukee from the society's Circus World Museum in Baraboo, where the Ringling brothers organized their original road show at the family farm in the 19th century. Police traditionally say 500,000 watch the parade, but acknowledge it is mathematically unlikely that many people could be accommodated along a four-mile route. No other attendance figure is officially issued.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Trouble Not a Total Loss, Scientist Says
DOC.TEXT: The $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope is not a total loss despite the blurring of its giant eye by a misshapen mirror, a scientist told a convention of astronomers on Sunday. Eric Chaisson, an adjunct professor of physics at Johns Hopkins University, said the troubled telescope still can provide scientists with information. ``We can view bright objects with decent resolution, but we won't be able to see the faintest objects in the universe,'' Chaisson said. ``That, frankly, is what the Hubble had made its name on. That is compromised.'' Hubble's biggest mission was to peer into the universe's distant corners. The telescope, launched April 25, has a focusing flaw that has sharply reduced its usefulness. Because of an error in the grinding and polishing of the Hubble's main mirrors, it cannot capture crisp, clean pictures of distant stars. An investigation into the problem is continuing. The head of the NASA probe, Dr. Lew Allen, told Congress last week that it may take more than six months to pinpoint the error in the telescope production. Chaisson is a senior scientist at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, the group charged with overseeing Hubble's scientific explorations. When the convention of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific was organized, Chaisson was slated to speak about Hubble's early findings. Instead, he found himself focusing on the Hubble's woes in his presentation before several hundred astronomers. ``You're going to have to stretch your imagination a little bit,'' Chaisson said. ``There is a problem, clearly, we can't get around that. But Hubble is not broken. There is still a lot of exciting science to come out of it.'' Chaisson showed a slide of the constellation Orion taken by Hubble that had slightly greater clarity than one taken from groud-based telescope. ``Hubble already shows starfields better than any ground-based telescope,'' he said. Hubble had been expected to far surpass the capabilities of observatory telescopes, which must peer up at the stars through Earth's atmosphere. With its focusing problem, Hubble will be unable to pick out distant stars to determine the size of the universe, Chaisson said. Nor will it be able to search the heavens for objects invisible to ground-based telescopes, like planets in other solar systems or extremely distant stellar objects, he said. Chaisson held out hope that when replacement instruments are finally installed in 1993, Hubble will be able to complete much of its mission over its planned 15-year lifetime.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Keep Bridge Blocked in Canadian Land Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Indians locked in a land dispute with authorities reversed themselves Sunday and kept up their blockade of a bridge into Montreal. The Mohawks said they decided not to lift the blockade, as promised, because authorities had reneged on a promise to reduce a police contingent in Oka, about 20 miles west of Montreal. The town was the scene of a shootout Wednesday between authorities and Mohawks manning barricades to block the expansion of a golf course. The Indians say the expansion would occur on their ancestral land. One police officer was killed in the confrontation, but it is not clear if he was shot by Mohawks or fellow officers. Talks aimed at ending the Oka standoff between armed Mohawks and police continued Sunday. Quebec province was represented by Native Affairs Minister John Ciaccia. He said Sunday he believed that the two sides were close to patching up their agreement of the night before. ``We have obtained the cooperation of Quebec police,'' said Ciaccia. ``They have reduced the number of personnel _ however, not in such a way as to affect our own security,'' he said. He refused to say how many of the estimated 1,000 police officers at Oka have pulled out. The Mohawks of the Kahnawake reserve blocked the Mercier bridge on Wednesday in sympathy with the Oka Indians. The bridge blockade enraged some residents, who faced massive traffic jams trying to get into Montreal from the south shore of the St. Lawrence River by alternate routes. On Saturday evening, a mob of about 2,000 residents gathered at the boundary of the Kahnawake reserve and shouted racist slurs at the natives. At one point, they burned a dummy bearing the words ``Non aux Warriors,'' or ``no to the Warriors.'' They also chanted war whoops, danced and waved Quebec flags. The crowd dispersed only after Ciaccia emerged from six hours of talks with native negotiators in Oka and promised the bridge blockage would be lifted. He said provincial authorities would make a ``significant reduction'' in their Oka police contingent in exchange. But in a statement released Sunday, the Mohawk council of Kahnawake said the deal was off because police forces had been boosted both at Oka and near the Mercier bridge. On Sunday, a crowd of about 500 people gathered again at the bridge. The afternoon started quietly as people carrying binoculars and potato chips installed their folding lawn chairs near police barricades to watch developments. Later, the crowd became restive and cheered as an effigy of a Mohawk carrying a bow and arrow was hung from a lamppost. One nearby resident, Irene O'Brien-Neil, was scratched and punched by two women when she arrived wearing an Indian beadwork collar. ``I'm all for the Indians,'' she said, clutching a tuft of hair she pulled from one of her attackers. ``It's their land. I'm inconvenienced like everybody else at this barricade, but they have rights.'' Alain Lauzier, a truck driver, had other views. ``What I want to know is: what happens the day after the bridge is opened and we drive through Kahnawake? Are my wife and kids going to be faced with guns from these guys?'' Meanwhile, in Oka, a town of 3,000, police and the Indians from the reservation there stared at each other across their own sets of barricades. About 1,000 police officers blocked access to the town. Police also prevented anyone from taking food into the Mohawk-occupied area. Also Sunday, Gilles Landreville, acting mayor of Oka, said, ``We don't think it's normal that a minister goes over there and negotiates with people who have committed criminal acts,'' he said. He was referring to the negotiations between Ciaccia and Mohawk representatives. ``We are asking that they give up their arms, and then we can start negotiating.'' In Calgary on Saturday, Don Mazankowski, the national government's deputy prime minister, said Ottawa is ready to establish a committee to try to settle the dispute if blockades are lifted and guns laid down.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Police Chase Asylum-seeker Into Spain's Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Cuban police violated the grounds of Spain's embassy in Havana by chasing an asylum-seeker into the compound and hauling him away, the Foreign Ministry said Sunday. Also Sunday, the official Mexican news agency reported that a group of 30 Czechoslovak diplomats and dependents had left Havana, apparently as a result of tensions over Cuban refugees at the Czechoslovak embassy. Three other Cubans have taken refuge in the Spain's embassy and 12 Cubans are at the Czechoslovak embassy. The Spanish ambassador to Havana, Antonio Serrano, lodged a protest with Cuban Foreign Minister Isidoro Malmierca after Cuban police jumped over the iron gate to the Spanish embassy on Friday while pursuing a young Cuban. The police detained the man. In his reply, Malmierca said there had been no intention of violating the embassy and offered assurances that there would be no repeat of such actions, said the Spanish Foreign Ministry spokesman, Juan Lena. Malmierca said the chase had begun outside the embassy grounds. Lena said the Spanish government had asked Cuban authorities not to take reprisals against the young man detained on the embassy grounds. He said an undetermined number of Spanish policemen would be sent to Havana to protect the embassy. Lena reiterated that Spain would not hand over the three Cubans who sought refuge at the Spanish embassy last week. He said his country was seeking to arrange their departure for Spain or a third country. The Spanish news agency EFE said Cuba's Communist leader, Fidel Castro, had guaranteed the security of foreign embassies in Cuba during a talk with foreign reporters at a Bastille Day reception Saturday at the French embassy. However, Castro was quoted by EFE as saying the refugees in the Spanish and Czechoslovak embassies were ``anti-social elements without any patriotic motivation.'' On Saturday, the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry in Prague said two of the 14 Cubans who sought refuge at its embassy in Havana had left the mission. One Cuban left without notifying the embassy staff, and the other asked to leave without giving any explanation. The influx of asylum-seekers has heightened tensions between Cuba and Czechoslovakia, which were close allies before last fall's democratic upheaval toppled Prague's hard-line Communist leaders. Castro has resisted the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, sticking to his orthodox Marxist policies. The Mexican news agency, Notimex, did not say when the 30 Czechoslovak diplomats and dependents left the country. It quoted unidentified European diplomatic sources as saying they were among a group of about 70 Czechoslovak embassy personnel and family members who had been warned to leave the country. The Notimex dispatch from Havana, monitored in Mexico, did not give details about the warning other than to say the Czechoslovaks ``had received a recommendation to leave the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Clan Gather To Honor Matriarch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to RECAST lead, CLARIFY that most of party was over when Rose wheeled onto porch; picks up 5th graf pvs, ```As she...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HYS1, HYS4
DOC.TEXT: A glittering assembly of Kennedys and other dignitaries saluted Rose Kennedy on her 100th birthday, although the honored matriarch was in poor health and absent during most of the celebration. The 370 guests attended the party in a large tent on Mrs. Kennedy's lawn a few yards from Nantucket Sound. Four of her five surviving children were present, as were most of her 28 grandchildren and 22 great-grandchildren. Around 5 p.m., after the lunch and speeches were over, a nurse briefly wheeled Mrs. Kennedy, flanked by a few members of her clan, out on the porch of her home. Earlier, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy had given a testimonial to his mother but said he didn't expect her at the festivities because of her frail health. ``As she told me just a few days ago,'' he said, ```I'm like old wine _ they don't bring me out very often, but I'm well preserved.''' The Massachusetts Democrat was joined by his ex-wife Joan Kennedy; by Ethel Kennedy, the widow of his brother Robert Kennedy; and by Kennedy sisters Patricia Kennedy Lawford, Jean Kennedy Smith and Eunice Shriver. Their mentally retarded sister, Rosemary, remained in a Wisconsin nursing home. ``In the chaos of our household, she was the quiet at the center of the storm, the anchor of our family, the safe harbor to which we always came,'' said the 58-year-old Edward Kennedy, the youngest of nine children of Rose and the late Joseph P. Kennedy. ``She always stressed the importance of family loyalty and family strength,'' said Mrs. Shriver, standing before a photographic exhibit of her mother's life. ``She taught us we were much stronger as a family than as individuals.'' The birthday celebration was held a week before Mrs. Kennedy's July 22 birthday. A smaller group will visit with her next Sunday. The guests were seated in a large tent at small tables under a huge portrait taken of Mrs. Kennedy in 1980, her chin up and wearing a red hat. The family and their guests ate from a buffet of poached salmon, turkey, lobster and scallop salad and pasta primavera. Each table held a bouquet of pink roses and a tiny framed portrait of Mrs. Kennedy in a floral frame. Many of the guests wept during the showing of a film of Mrs. Kennedy's life, narrated by her son. Singer Maureen McGovern performed a medley of Mrs. Kennedy's favorite Irish songs, including ``Rose of Tralee'' before the gathering sang ``Happy Birthday.'' President John F. Kennedy's daughter, Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, attended but her mother, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and her brother, John Jr., did not. TV reporter Maria Shriver, 34, and her husband, Arnold Schwarzenegger, arrived with their baby daughter, Katherine, dressed in a red polka dot playsuit and red shoes. Maria Shriver is the daughter of Eunice and Sargent Shriver. Members of the Kennedy family spoke prior to the luncheon ceremony about their contributions to the field of mental retardation.
