Robert Kennedy Jr., 36, with his son clinging to his side, spoke of his involvement in an inter-generational home for teen-age mothers and elderly people in New York's inner city. Robert's brother Chris Kennedy, 26, said he has been directing a model preschool program in Chicago, which mixes mentally retarded children with average kids. ``One of the things that has made the greatest difference to our mother is the work in which the current generation (of Kennedys) is involved,'' Sen. Kennedy said. ``Mother told them and us that that is her greatest birthday present.'' Many of the guests were specialists in the field of mental retardation. Also attending were humorist Art Buchwald; Kennedy historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr.; Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and his wife, Kitty; Secretary of Education Lauro Cavazos; actor Tom Hulce; and champion skier Billy Kidd, who is involved with the Special Olympics for mentally retarded children. The master of ceremonies was Robert MacNeil of ``The MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour.'' Four of Rose's children died in tragic circumstances. Her eldest son, Joe Jr., was killed flying a secret Navy mission in 1944; daughter Kathleen died in a plane crash in France. President Kennedy was assassinated in 1963, and in 1968 Robert Kennedy was shot to death in Los Angeles while he campaigned for the presidency.

DOC.HEAD: Margaret Lockwood, British Film Star, Dies At 73
DOC.TEXT: Actress Margaret Lockwood, the beautiful brunette who starred in Alfred Hitchcock's 1938 classic ``The Lady Vanishes'' and reigned over Britain's film industry in the 1940s, died Sunday. She was 73. A Cromwell Hospital statement said the family had asked for no other details to be released. Born in Karachi, Pakistan, on Sept. 15, 1916, she had her first stage role at age 12 as a fairy in Shakespeare's ``A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' She trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and made her first film, ``Lorna Doone,'' when she was 19. Other notable films included ``Night Train to Munich,'' ``The Man in Gray,'' and the 1945 hit ``The Wicked Lady.'' Parts of ``The Wicked Lady'' had to be reshot before it could be screened in the United States because her neckline was considered too daring. In ``The Wicked Lady,'' with James Mason, she played an aristocratic lady who joins a highwayman in his life of crime. ``Once there was a period when no British film seemed complete without her getting severely bruised in period costume by James Mason,'' the critic Sheridan Morley wrote last year. By 1957, she had acted in more than 40 films. Her last film appearance was in 1976 in a cameo role in ``The Slipper and the Rose.'' She was featured in the popular 1960s British Broadcasting Corp. series ``The Flying Swan,'' co-starring her daughter Julia, and in a series called ``Justice'' in the 1970s. In the 1940s, she was twice named biggest money-earner of British cinema. She also enjoyed a rich stage career that continued until 1980 as Queen Alexandra in a short-lived production of ``Motherdear.'' Her father, a railway clerk in the British colonial service in India, had little contact with her. Her mother disapproved of her first love, Rupert Leon, a London commodities clerk, and they married in secret. He disliked her film career. He followed her to Hollywood where she worked briefly, and they were divorced during World War II. Later, she had to fight a bitter court battle to win custody of Julia, her only child. She never remarried, and in her last years lived a modest, reclusive life in suburban London.

DOC.HEAD: General Who Implicated Imelda Marcos in Coup Plot Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS four grafs for 5-7 bgng `Mrs. Marcos...' to ADD that Mrs. Marcos had not said she was involved in attempted coup; CORRECT name of Wrightwood, dropping ``City'' from name; pickup graf 8 `U.S. officials...'
DOC.TEXT: Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido, who implicated Imelda Marcos and an American in a failed December coup, died early Sunday of liver cancer, officials said. He was 54. Galido gave up his post as chief of the military's southern Luzon command in December after he was himself linked to the bloody nine-day coup attempt. It killed 113 people and nearly toppled President Corazon Aquino. Later, Chief of Staff Renato de Villa said Galido had infiltrated ranks of military dissidents to spy on them for the government. In a statement given in February, Galido said he telephoned Mrs. Marcos in Hawaii last year to ask for financial backing for a coup attempt, but she refused because of money problems. However, she has never said she was involved in the coup attempt. Mrs. Marcos, wife of the late Philippine leader Ferdinand Marcos, was acquitted July 2 after a 10-week trial in U.S. District Court in New York. The government had alleged that she helped her husband loot the Philippines' treasury of more than $220 million, using the money to buy four New York buildings, artworks and jewelry. Mrs. Aquino was swept into power when a military-civilian uprising ousted President Marcos in February 1986. Galido also said an American, Harold Maglio of Wrightwood, Calif., offered to sell him $20 million worth of weapons for the attempted coup. Galido said Maglio introduced himself as an Air Force colonel working for the Defense Intelligence Agency. U.S. officials said Maglio worked at Norton Air Force Base in southern California but had no links to the Defense Intelligence Agency. Galido was born July 12, 1936, in Antique province. He graduated from the Philippine Military Academy in 1958 and served primarily in intelligence positions. He also served with the Philippine contingent in Vietnam during the 1960s. He is survived by his widow, Consalacion, six sons and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Hopes Museum will Help Render Kinder Judgment of His Career
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon doesn't expect the news media ever to love him, but the man who resigned the presidency in disgrace thinks the public will judge him more kindly once people tour his new library. The Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library and Birthplace will be dedicated Thursday in Yorba Linda, in a ceremony to be attended by President Bush and former Presidents Reagan, Ford and Nixon himself. The gathering is also expected to include the largest reunion of Nixon administration officials since the ex-president's second inauguration in 1972. On the eve of the celebration, Nixon told the Los Angeles Times he believes the library will help remove much of the taint of the Watergate scancal that resulted in his resigning in disgrace. ``Over time, as their interest fades, and if the public continues to visit the Nixon museum, I would think that all the events covered will be seen in a more objective perspective,'' Nixon commented. The president's written remarks, in answer to questions submitted by the Times, were published Sunday. Nixon said the news media area are still obsessed with finding a sinister purpose in his activities. Historians are too liberal ever to be sympathetic to his cause, he said. But he doesn't ``waste time worrying'' about his political legacy, Nixon said; nor does he give any thought to ``my so-called political rehabilitation.'' Nixon, 77, resigned office in 1974 amid allegations he helped cover up a botched political burglary of Democratic Party headquarters in the Watergate apartment complex in Washington. A pardon from Ford kept Nixon from facing any possible charges. Library officials say the $21 million complex will have an extensive Watergate section, along with many other exhibits showing the more positive aspects of Nixon's career. The exhibits will showcase Nixon's foreign policy triumphs and the adoption of the Clean Air Act and creation of the Environmental Protection Agency during his administration.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Rescue Hikers Trapped on Mount Whitney By Storm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to UPDATE with identification of victim.
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers brought more stranded climbers down from towering Mount Whitney on Sunday, a day after lightning struck a stone hut and killed one of the 13 hikers seeking shelter there from a thunderstorm. The body of Matthew Nordbrock, 26, of Orange was flown Saturday from the summit of 14,495-foot Whitney, the tallest mountain in the contiguous United States, said Ann Melle, Inyo County sheriff's spokeswoman. Four other people who suffered minor injuries, exposure and burns also were rescued from the mountain Saturday. Three were treated and released, while the fourth was admitted to Southern Inyo Hospital in Lone Pine, Ms. Melle said. Eight more mountain enthusiasts who had crowded into the 12 feet-by-12 feet cabin were plucked from the mountain by cargo helicopter about 6 a.m. Sunday. They and two other climbers, who had made camp at a lower elevation, also were flown to the hospital for treatment. The deadly lightning bolt struck about 3:30 p.m. Saturday in the middle of a raging thunderstorm. Several hikers raced down from the summit for help and met someone with a two-way radio, said sheriff's Lt. Jack Goodrich. The frantic radio SOS was intercepted by a jetliner passing overhead. Pilots notified air traffic controllers at Los Angeles International Airport and the controllers passed the emergency call on to Inyo County authorities. Rescue efforts began shortly before nightfall. The victim was pronounced dead at the hospital about an hour after he was brought in. The stone structure the hikers packed into was built in 1909 for astronomers. It is not recommended as a shelter. ``The hut at the top is not there for hikers,'' Ms. Melle said. ``It's just an old, old structure. This is back country area. Anyone who is up here is expected to be prepared. Mountain tops are dangerous places to be.'' Authorities had no plans to close the trail, Ms. Melle said. ``Mount Whitney is known for unusual storms,'' she said. ``It's a very severe peak. Bad weather conditions are expected and weather forecasts had predicted bad conditions.'' Ms. Melle said up to 300 people attempt to scale the mountain each day during the busy summer climbing season. Experienced mountaineers usually take two days to hike the roughly 16 miles to Mount Whitney's summit from the trailhead at 9,000 feet, near Lone Pine. The mountain's majestic peak can be seen for miles along the eastern Sierra Nevada range.

DOC.HEAD: Seattle Homeless Activist Shot
DOC.TEXT: A leading Seattle advocate for the homeless was shot and critically wounded at his shelter after a fight with another tenant, who apparently fired in self-defense, police said. Robert Willmott, 60, underwent surgery after being shot in the neck and chest late Saturday night, said nursing supervisor Rosie Davis, at Harborview Medical Center. Mitchell Washington, 36, told police that he shot Willmott with a .22-caliber rifle after Willmott, brandishing a rifle of his own, burst into the room at the Strand Helpers shelter where Washington's family was sleeping. Washington also said Willmott had threatened him with a pistol about 10 hours before the shooting took place. The only witnesses to the shooting were Washington's wife and four children, but the evidence at the scene corroborated Washington's statement, and he was released after questioning, said police spokeswoman Tina Drain. Wilmott founded Strand Helpers, a private group relying on donations and volunteer work, in 1982. A brochure from the group said it had served more than 1.3 million meals and provided 280,000 people with free nights of housing. Willmott, who ran unsuccessfully for mayor last year, often clashed with city authorities over housing policy.

DOC.HEAD: Police Captain Hints at Involvement of Superiors in Priest Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A letter from a secret police captain convicted in the 1984 murder of a pro-Solidarity priest has hinted that the slaying was not a renegade act, but officially sanctioned by senior government officials. The former secret police officer, Grzegorz Piotrowski, is serving a lengthy prison sentence for his role in the October 1984 murder of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko. The priest was an outspoken supporter of the then-outlawed Solidarity labor union, and his slaying shocked the country. The text of a letter from Piotrowski to former Interior Minister Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak was published Friday in the pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza. It bore no date, but was apparently written several years ago. Piotrowski and three other secret police officers were quickly arrested, tried and sentenced for the killing, but many Poles viewed the proceedings as a coverup to prevent the implication of more senior officials. In his letter, Piotrowski implicates senior officials in the Interior Ministry. Gazeta Wyborcza cautioned its readers that Piotrowski's allegations had not been independently verified and should be treated with caution because Piotrowski might not be credible. Piotrowski was quoted as saying he was not sure if his letter ever reached Kiszczak, who headed the interior ministry at the time of the slaying. Kiszczak played a major role in the 1989 negotiations that led to the establishment of a Solidarity-led government. He was dismissed as interior minister earlier this month. During his trial, prosecutors maintained that Piotrowski was the ringleader in the priest's killing and had committed the crime at the instigation of his direct superior officer, Interior Ministry Col. Adam Pietruszka. In his letter, Piotrowski wrote: ``General, our actions were not an act of lawlessness but an act of devotion and subordination to the Service, and you know this.'' In the letter, in which he appears to be pleading for better treatment in prison, Piotrowski added that he kept silent during his trial out of a feeling of loyalty to the security service, and not because of ``persuasion and promises'' made by a deputy to Kiszczak. Piotrowski was originally sentenced in February 1985 to 25 years in prison, but his sentence was reduced to 15 years in December 1987. Convicted with Piotrowski were his subordinates, two secret police lieutenants, and his supervisor, Pietruszka, who did not take part in the actual killing but was convicted of instigating the crime. In his letter, Piotrowski wrote: ``Before the court I took on myself the entire weight _ a silence which could have cost me my life.'' He wrote that the court was not informed that the security service had routinely violated the law and constitution by harassing and eavesdropping on church figures. ``The force carried out similar tasks very often, getting awards and praise for them, even from the leadership of the interior ministry,'' Piotrowski said.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatric Patients Stabs Four Jewish Children
DOC.TEXT: A psychiatric patient screaming anti-Semitic slogans stabbed four children in the playground of a Jewish school Monday morning, police said. The children, ranging in age from 6 to 8, were hospitalized after the attack. It occurred before classes started at the Hebrew Congregation's Kadimah College and Kindergarten school. Witnesses said the woman was shouting anti-Semitic slogans as she rushed into the playground and began stabbing the screaming children. She was disarmed by a male teacher on duty at the playground. Staff members and parents rushed to help the injured chilren as schoolmates watched in horror. Parents bringing their children to the morning assembly rushed them inside, where there were tearful scenes as students tried to come to terms with what had happened. The hospitalized children were identified as 6-year-old twins Nicholas and Samuel Henderson; Damon Bree, 8; and Simon Clark, 6. Their conditions were not immediately available. One suffered a stomach wound, another sustained a punctured lung, and a third was stabbed in the shoulder. The fourth was undergoing surgery for unspecified wounds. The school, which has 200 students, offers programs for children from pre-school age to 12 years old. Police Detective Inspector Mike Crawford said the woman would face four charges of attempted murder in a court appearance later Monday. He did not identify her but said she was an outpatient of Carrington psychiatric hospital in Auckland. Police recovered a kitchen knife with a 4-inch-long blade after the attack. Jewish leaders said the woman was not connected with the school. A Jewish student outside the school said the suspect in the attack had been there Saturday to see an art exhibition. The student said she had been turned away when she threatened a woman attendant and made a nuisance of herself. Auckland Hebrew Congregation president Michael Kutner said school security would be reviewed at a meeting Monday night. ``It appears to be one crazed person _ an isolated incident _ not part of a wave of violence,'' he said. Jewish leaders said they hoped the incident will not spark copycat anti-Semitic incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BAGHDAD
Arafat Rejects U.S. Conditions for Resuming Dialogue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Arafat rejecting U.S. condition for dialogue; PRECEDE to Tunis; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: PLO chairman Yasser Arafat on Sunday rejected U.S. demands to discipline a guerrilla leader responsible for an attempted seaborne raid on Isrel. Arafat made his remarks during a meeting at the Arab League's Tunis headquarters of foreign ministers and delegates from the 21 member countries. The meeting was called to consider the fallout from the recent break in the dialogue between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Washington said it would not resume the dialogue with the PLO unless the organization renounced the seaborne raid and took action against Abul Abbas. His Palestinian guerrilla group, a PLO faction, claimed responsibility for the May 30 assault foiled by Israeli forces. ``It's out of the question for the PLO to bend itself to these conditions,'' Arafat told the closed-door session, according to participants in the meeting. The PLO chairman also accused the United States of ``supporting Israel without limit,'' participants said. Arafat spoke after the PLO's chief delegate to the Arab League, Mahmoud Abbas, urged ``concrete and efficient measures'' to protect Arab interests following the suspension of the dialogue. Mahmoud Abbas is not related to Abul Abbas. The delegate did not define what form such measures to protect Arab interests would take, but he urged Arab countries to prepare a response if Israel attacks either Iraq or Libya. The meeting started late Sunday and was likely to stretch into Monday, observers said. The Arab League representatives were also considering problems caused by the massive immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. League sources said the PLO wants the Arab countries to condemn President Bush's decision to break off the U.S. dialogue with the PLO. The PLO wants the United States to resume the dialogue, begun in December 1988 after Arafat renounced terrorism and backed the right of Israel to exist. Earlier Sunday, the PLO indefinitely postponed a meeting of its Central Council scheduled for Wednesday in Baghdad, Iraq. The meeting had been called to discuss the suspended dialogue with the United States. The meeting would also have discussed how to respond to the new right-wing Israeli government headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The PLO's representative to Iraq, Azzam Ahmed, said the meeting was called off ``to allow for more consultations.'' He said no new date had been set for the meeting. Bush severed the dialogue with the PLO following the foiled seaborne raid on a civilian-filled beach that was carried out by Abul Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front, one of nine factions under the umbrella of the PLO. In the raid, four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. There were no Israeli casualties. Washington has demanded that Abul Abbas be dismissed from the PLO's Executive Committee for his role in the attack. The PLO serves as an umbrella organization for guerrilla factions that sometimes fight among themselves and launch independent attacks on Israeli targets. The largest group is Arafat's mainstream Fatah.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Besiege Provincial Capitals, Make Major Military Gains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT typo in name of Savoeun
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
LaserPhotos NY5,6
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press correspondent Nate Thayer spent five weeks with Cambodian guerrillas deep inside Cambodia, the first Western journalist to make such a trip during the 11-year-old war. This is his report.

NATIONAL HIGHWAY 6, Cambodia (AP) _ Guerrillas have seized hundreds of villages and military positions in northern Cambodia, forcing the army to fall back and defend besieged provincial capitals. Evidence of the most significant guerrilla gains in more than 11 years of fighting was clear during a five-week trip with the insurgents that covered 450 miles. The three-party guerrilla coalition, which includes the Communist Khmer Rouge, controls large areas of the north and northwest. The insurgents are shelling and launching commando raids on key provincial capitals. Senior guerrilla commanders say the attacks are in preparation for full-scale assaults on the cities of Kompong Thom and Siem Reap, and the ancient temples of Angkor near Siem Reap. During the trip, hundreds of government artillery shells and rockets landed daily, shaking the paddies of a beautiful rice-growing region engulfed by war. Debris from bridges blown up by guerrillas littered highways. The jungle fighters set up ambushes to attack convoys trying to resupply forward government outposts defending the major urban areas. Guerrilla medics trained in China ran field hospitals, dressing wounds and amputating limbs. As the guerrillas advance, the world seeks a political solution and worries that the Khmer Rouge, whose bloody regime was overthrown by a Vietnamese invasion in December 1978, may regain power. More than a million Cambodians were killed or died of starvation during 3{ years of Khmer Rouge rule. Khmer Rouge commanders expressed confidence they would capture Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital. They used maps to illustrate encirclement from the north, south and west _ similar to the strategy in 1975, when the Khmer Rouge defeated the U.S.-backed government of President Lon Nol. The trip, with an escort of guerrillas loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the coalition, began on the Thai border and covered three northern provinces. Included was a 30-mile stretch of National Highway 6, a government lifeline to outlying provinces, now in guerrilla hands. It provided the first independent confirmation of the guerillas' claims that they have advanced deep inside the country. Thousands of Sihanouk's guerrillas were seen lounging in villages, shopping in bustling markets and manning lines around Kompong Thom, which they said was their next target. Kompong Thom, a strategic crossroads city, is 90 miles north of Phnom Penh. In separate attacks, the Khmer Rouge was advancing toward Siem Reap, 200 miles northwest of Phnom Penh, and was within reach of the Angkor temples. ``We have taken all the positions around Siem Reap, isolating the town,'' said Ta Pok, a Khmer Rouge brigade commander interviewed at his jungle base north of the city. ``We are winning everywhere we are fighting,'' said Col. Khan Savoeun, a commander of forces loyal to Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler, at headquarters in Stoeung, the de facto capital of what the Sihanoukists call their liberated zone. In the war's early stages, most guerrillas were in bases along the Thai border and obtaining weapons from China was easy, given Thailand's support for the insurgents. Now the lines have shifted far from the frontier. The Sihanouk forces and the Khmer Rouge have forged a network of thousands of miles of secret roads and trails into the interior. Convoys of trucks, oxcarts and thousands of civilian supporters were seen daily moving supplies from jungle caches to forward areas. Convoys of Chinese-supplied trucks and captured government vehicles moved freely along sections of provincial highways that were under government control less than a year ago. More than 50,000 insurgents are fighting an army that has superior firepower, but is mostly conscripts reported to be poorly trained. The guerrilla groups led by Sihanouk and Son Sann are non-Communist, but the Khmer Rouge is by far the strongest. The war took a favorable turn for the guerrillas last fall, when Vietnam withdrew most of its soldiers, leaving the forces of Premier Hun Sen to face the battle-tested guerrillas alone. ``Sometimes I think Hun Sen is stupid; you know we don't need to negotiate with him now,'' said Mit Lot, Khmer Rouge deputy division commander at a base 12 miles from the Angkor Wat ruins. ``If they don't compromise, they will lose everything. At this rate the war will be over by the end of the year.'' Although the Khmer Rouge is the most powerful force in the coalition, it seemed clear during the trip that the non-Communists had gained considerable support and scored significant military victories. The Khmer Rouge has little public support because of its history, and that hampers its effectiveness in more heavily populated areas. Sihanouk's commanders described a raid by 400 commandos who briefly seized Kompong Thom in late June. They destroyed military positions and tested the waters for what guerrilla field commanders said would be a full-scale attack on the provincial capital. Heavy weapons could be seen in place less than five miles from the city and rockets were being fired at Kompong Thom. The Sihanouk forces claim to control more than 700 towns and villages. A major source of their strength appears to be wide public support for Sihanouk, revered by many as a god-king during his reign. Around Stoeng, on Highway 6 less than a 30-minute drive from Kompong Thom, non-Communists control the largest area of Indochina since the Americans left 15 years ago. Followers of Sihanouk have trained hundreds of civilian administrators, teachers and medical personnel and begun an aggressive effort to re-establish Buddhism. Thousands of children were seen attending primary schools. Dozens of Buddhist temples were being refurbished and others built. While the Sihanoukists and Khmer Rouge are in a loose coalition, tension between the groups was evident. ``For the time being, we share common military goals with the Khmer Rouge, but we are in full control here,'' said Col. Khan Savoeun, commander of the Kompong Thom area. ``The Khmer Rouge understand strength, and we are very strong in Kompong Thom.''

DOC.HEAD: Shoot Ends with No Protest, Nearly 3,000 Rodents Dispatched
Laserphotos NATX1,2
DOC.TEXT: Hunters bagged nearly 3,000 prairie dogs in a weekend shootout and the gleeful organizers of the event said howls of protest from animal rights activists had done nothing but attract more business. When the shoot was announced in April it drew criticism from Gov. Roy Romer and Democratic Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, but Mayor John Vanderpool and shoot organizer Mike Mehew told the pols to ``buzz off.'' On Sunday, Mehew said he was grateful for their attentions, which drew additional hunters and news media to the event. He said he planned to write thank-you notes to Romer, Campbell and Robin Duxbury of the Rocky Mountain Humane Society. Shoot participants weren't put off by the smattering of protest either. ``All their noise does is bring the prairie dogs out of their holes to see what's doing on,'' said Terrye Logan, 32, of Clyde, Texas, one of three women competing in the event. ``My brothers yesterday ended up laughing so hard they had to put their guns down.'' The 106 shooters at the first Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot slew a total of 2,956 prairie dogs in the two-day event. The top killers were local rancher Earl Reams and his partner, Randy Calhoun, who dispatched 112 prairie dogs to win two top-of-the line Kimber rifles. More important to local merchants, the event brought an economic boost to the neighboring western Colorado towns of Nucla and Naturita, which have been devastated by range droughts and a bust in uranium mining. ``We did enough in four days to double what we do in an entire (big game) hunting season,'' said Beulah Colcord, owner of the Yellow Rock Cafe in Naturita. ``And we couldn't be happier with the protesters. They made the publicity that brought all these people in here.'' Among the popular kitschy items on sale were ``critter coffins,'' sold at $20-$35 each by Joe Hale and Rod Gerken of Hale & Gerken Funeral Home in Naturita. ``I've got this little office just fill of prairie dog caskets and we have about 150 orders,'' Hale said. Proceeds were going to needy families, he said. The hunters, resting their rifles on car hoods or shooting from benches, popped their shots off into a desolate plain scarred by the six-inch mounds and burrows of the prairie dogs. More than $7,000 in prizes was taken home by hunters who came from North Carolina to California for the competition. It was billed as a way of reducing the population of the foot-tall, grayish brown rodents, relatives of the squirrel. Ranchers say the prairie dogs carry bubonic plague and ruin fields that might be planted in oats. Cattle break their legs stumbling into the holes. Only about two dozen protesters were on hand Saturday morning, and the number dwindled over the weekend. Not surpisingly, none of the picketers stuck around for the celebratory picnic Sunday evening. Three protesters in their early 20s appeared Sunday morning, blowing whistles and holding signs. ``If nothing else, we're bothering the mighty hunters,'' said Jon Ellenbogen, 24. ``I don't take their arguments about damage from prairie dogs. If the prairie dogs are ruining it for the cows, don't raise cows. Shooting them is not much of a philosophy.'' Shoot winner Reams, president of the West End Cattlemen's Association, said the contest had boosted local pride. ``This is a rural community where we have guns and do a lot of shooting. Some places have theaters, we have turkey shoots. This is good for the town and now we're on the map.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Tries to Go Over Falls in Barrel for Second Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Munday; and to DELETE outdated grafs. Picks up 12th graf pvs: `Two park ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BF1
DOC.TEXT: A daredevil who went over Niagara Falls in a barrel in 1985 tried again Sunday but low water stranded his barrel at the brink of the falls, police said. The barrel carrying Dave Munday, 53, stopped a foot before the brink of the 176-foot Horseshoe Falls on the Canadian side of the Niagara River. Police used a crane to fish the daredevil and his barrel out of the river rapids. Niagara Parks Police, who patrol the park along the Canadian side of the twin waterfalls, said Munday's barrel was dropped into the river about 660 feet upstream of the Horseshoe Falls about 4:40 a.m. The Ontario Hydro electric utility had been diverting half the river's flow overnight to power its hydroelectric plant, said police spokesman George Bailey. The low river level helped snag the barrel on the falls' rocky ledge, he said. Munday ``really doesn't know the river like a lot of people thought he did,'' Bailey said. ``There was very little water going over the falls, and he probably could have guessed that he would get stuck.'' ``I've never been a religious man, but something stopped it,'' Munday told The Associated Press Sunday night from his home in Caistor Center, Ontario. ``Probably I would have been dead if it went over.'' Mundy said he was lying on his side inside the 650-pound, 7-foot-long barrel when it became stuck. He said part of the barrel actually hung over the edge of the falls. ``If you tried it a thousand times you wouldn't be able to get it to do that again,'' he said. Munday was the seventh person to successfully go over the falls in a vessel. Three others before him died. After his 1985 trip, Munday told reporters, ``Anyone who would go over the falls twice would have to be crazy.'' But since then, he had boasted that he would do it again one day. Had he been successful Sunday, Munday would have become the first person to survive two trips over the falls. During Sunday's attempt, the steel and foam barrel lodged on the riverbed a foot from the Table Rock tourist area at the brink of the falls, police said. Two park constables were able to bring the barrel to a wall at the edge of the falls and secure it there while a crane was brought to the site. The constables fashioned a sling and, using long poles, positioned the barrel so it could be lifted up and away from the brink. The rescue took two hours and ``put two people's lives in jeopardy,'' Bailey said. When the barrel was lowered into the tourist area, Munday emerged and was charged with violating laws that prohibit river stunts. He faces a fine of up to $10,000 _ about $8,500 in U.S. dollars. Police kept Munday's barrel. After his first ride, Munday was fined the maximum $1,000 for trespassing and $500 for the stunt itself. In March, the maximum fine was raised to $10,000 to discourage such stunts, Bailey said. Last month, a man who attempted to go over the falls in a kayak apparently lost his life in the stunt. The battered kayak belonging to Jessie Sharp, of Ocoee, Tenn., was found below the falls, but his body has not been recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, Seven Hospitalized in Stockton, Calif., Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen opened fire from their cars into a liquor store parking lot early Sunday, killing two people and leaving seven others hospitalized, police said. Witnesses said the assailants drove by in three cars and opened fire on the crowd of people, many of them customers of a taco wagon parked outside the liquor store. Sgt. Edward Williams said a fight over a woman had occurred, adding: ``Some of the fellows left and then subsequently returned with additional people, armed with what we believe at this time was a shotgun and a couple of rifles, and started firing on the people in the parking lot.'' Two men were arrested several hours after the 1:30 a.m. shooting, but their names weren't immediately available. Two teen-age men were killed, and of the seven people hospitalized in six area hospitals, three were listed in serious condition and four in stable condition, said police spokeswoman Dianne Cortez,

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Eskimo Dancers Arrive in Nome under Visa-Free Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Two Soviet Eskimo dancers are visiting northwest Alaska in the first instance such travel has been permitted without visas since 1948, authorities said Sunday. Misha Ankarin and Yakov Tagiok arrived in Nome Saturday on a special waiver granted by the U.S. State Department. The men were invited by the Nana Native Corp. in Kotzebue to spend the summer performing with that city's Northern Lights dancers. Tagiok, told reporters he hoped the first visa-free connection between U.S. and Soviet Eskimos would make future visits easier. The agreement for visa-free travel among Eskimos from the two nations was signed last year by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Eduard Shevardnadze, the Soviet foreign minister. The accord is still being finalized, and the visit by the Eskimo dancers was made as a goodwill gesture. Alaskan Eskimos have yet to be allowed to visit the Soviet Far East without visas. The agreement affects natives of the Bering Strait area of the Soviet Far East coast and from the Kobuk and Nome areas in Alaska. Ankarin and Tagiok are visiting friends and relatives in Nome and plan to stay in Alaska two to three months. They said they also may take trips to Anchorage and Fairbanks.

DOC.HEAD: 2,075-Acre Fire Nearly Contained in Oregon; Other Blazes Battled
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters had nearly contained a 2,075-acre fire in central Oregon Sunday just as the battle began to intensify against a blaze in the eastern part of the state. The second fire _ 20 miles southeast of John Day in eastern Oregon _ had consumed 300 acres by Sunday, said Jim Payne, fire staff officer for the Malheur National Forest. He said it was burning in subalpine fir and lodgepole pine. Temperatures in the 90s, low humidity and light winds were aiding growth of the blaze, which was consuming commercial timber and part of the Strawberry Mountain Wilderness. The fire's cause remained unknown. Some 500 firefighters were using two water-dropping helicopters, three bulldozers and several fire engines. ``The conditions are not real good,'' Payne said. ``Everything depends on the winds. If the winds don't push it around, we'll contain it. We'll have to wait and see.'' Meanwhile, the fire burning six miles southeast of Sisters in central Oregon was 90 percent contained Sunday and it was expected to be under control by 6 p.m. Tuesday, said Oregon Department of Forestry spokesman David Morman. In northern California's rural Santa Clara County, firefighters battled rugged terrain, dry winds and high temperatures Sunday while trying to contain a stubborn fire that burned 800 to 1,000 acres of grass and brush. Officials who earlier hoped to fully contain the fire 6{ miles northeast of Mount Hamilton reported 65 percent containment Sunday afternoon. Full containment was not expected until midnight Monday, the California Department of Forestry said. ``We're having problems with containment because of the steepness, wind and weather,'' said state forestry spokesman Chris Morgan. Temperatures were 85 to 90 with 10-12 mph winds, he said. Firefighters were using four air tankers. The cause still was under investigation. Only one building, an uninhabited log cabin, was burned. Although there are ranches in the area, no homes were in danger.

DOC.HEAD: Space Program Troubles Shake Congressional Confidence
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 8th graf ``Walsh added xxx to include NY Times report that reports of outside White House panel are premature
DOC.TEXT: The failure of the Hubble Space Telescope and grounding of the space shuttle fleet are shaking Congressional confidence in the space program just as lawmakers search for ways to redirect defense spending to civilian science. ``We were right on the edge of what all of us thought would be a new chapter at NASA,'' said Rep. Mike Andrews, D-Texas. Now, he says, cost overruns and defects in the Hubble telescope and shuttle program make the space agency look like ``just one more big bureaucracy.'' ``And now the Hubble. You know there's new information about the Hubble. Jay Leno has disclosed that it is actually working perfectly but the universe is all blurry,'' quipped Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., who conducted hearings on the telescope. Leno is a popular comedian who substitutes for Johnny Carson as host of ``The Tonight Show'' on NBC-TV. Reports indicate that the White House is preparing to name a panel of experts to review NASA operations in the wake of the embarrassing problems with the Hubble and the shuttle program. White House spokesman Sean Walsh said the Bush administration is conducting a ``broad review'' of the space program. ``Many ideas are being tossed around,'' he said in response to a Saturday CBS News report that the panel of experts probably will be named this week. Walsh added, however, that the administration will probably ``steer away from a major shakeup'' at NASA and The New York Times quoted unidentified administration officials in Monday's editions as saying no decision has been made on naming an outside review panel and that such reports were ``premature and overblown.'' Andrews, whose congressional district is home to thousands of NASA workers, and other boosters say there's still widespread support in Congress for space exploration. Two days after NASA revealed that the Hubble was crippled by a defective mirror, the House approved $14.3 billion for the agency in fiscal 1991, $2 billion more than the current fiscal year. There's little talk of any immediate cutbacks. But the agency's big projects for the future are being looked at with much more skepticism than before. Those include a $50 billion system of weather satellites, the $37 billion permanent space station, and President Bush's proposal to land a man on Mars within 30 years. ``The worse kept secret in Washington is that defense contractors who are out of work are now pushing space spending as a national priority,'' said Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., a member of the House Budget Committee. ``Where else can they spend billions of taxpayers' dollars on theory and dreams?'' More than $300 billion in new space projects have been proposed for the next three decades. But among ardent supporters in Congress, there is widespread reluctance to expand NASA's role before an accounting is made for the problems in the current programs. ``Their plate is quite full, and it's a very stressful time for NASA. Whatever can go wrong is going wrong,'' said Rep. Bob Traxler, D-Mich., chairman of the subcommittee that oversees the space and science budget. Rep. Bill Green of New York, the senior Republican on that panel, said a decision on pulling the plug on the space station project must be made soon or it could be too far along to kill. Traxler says it's too early to tell whether the program, already far over budget and under-capable, should be scrapped for something more simple. But he said Congress is increasingly skeptical of big science projects and especially of the promises made by their backers. The usual gambit for getting a big project approved is to come in with a low estimate, get Congress to sink money into it, and then expect Congress to keep spending as the estimates go up because so much money already is invested. ``Those days are gone,'' Traxler said. Andrews says NASA's problems run too deeply for Congress to solve without presidential leadership, and he's critical of Vice President Quayle for not doing more to straighten out NASA from his post as chairman of the National Space Council. ``I hope George Bush doesn't just leave it up to Dan Quayle to lead us through this difficult time,'' he said. For supporters of the defense establishment, one answer to NASA's problems can be found by leaving a little of the ``peace dividend'' under Pentagon control. ``You're already getting a huge amount of that,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Rep. Durbin, in a speech Friday, seemed to be skeptical either way. ``If the American taxpayers thought peace in the world meant an end to budgetary excesses of Pentagon contractors, the had their head in the clouds,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: States Looking More to Tax the Services Sector
DOC.TEXT: For decades, the sales tax in most states simply meant consumers had to pay a bit more money when they bought a car or a couch. But the shift toward a service-based economy has also brought changes in tax policy. Now when states are in a financial crunch they increasingly look to collect money each time a janitor mops a floor or even when an executive phones a lawyer for advice. In Massachusetts, the state Legislature recently passed a tax package that extends the sales tax to a broad range of services, including accounting fees for businesses and athletic club memberships. The move was a response to fiscal woes that over the last fiscal saw the state run up a deficit over $1 billion as its bond rating plummeted to the lowest ranking in the country. While Massachusetts is the latest state to consider taxing services, some experts do not expect a rush to follow. Although a services tax may be tempting it also can be fraught with administrative headaches. That means states probably will not take the step unless pushed by financial necessity. ``Talking about it is easier than implementing it,'' said Elaine Leon, director of taxpayer services for the Department of Revenue Services in Connecticut, which last year widely expanded its services tax. A handful of states tax some level of services, but many others have attempted the move and failed. Florida enacted a wide range of service taxes in 1987 but repealed them before the end of the year. Observers, however, blame the repeal on a political firestorm that accompanied the tax package rather than administrative difficulties. The sales tax generally dates to the Great Depression, when many states looking for money applied a levy on the purchase of tangible property. ``For most states, the sales tax was set up at a time when the country was more of a (manufacturing-based) economy,'' said Stephen Kidder, the Massachusetts commissioner of revenue. ``That's what has shifted over time.'' In fact, some tax experts argue that many of the economic forces that prompted growth in the sales tax in the 1930s also exist in the 1990s, making the taxation of services a stronger possibility. Nonetheless, most states have been hesitant to move into the services tax. Reasons often cited include a fear that the tax will add costs to businesses, which then will pass them along to consumers. Also, critics say the tax can hurt competitiveness in individual states, prompting some firms to locate elsewhere. Unlike cars or washing machines, which are defined easily by their physical presence, services have fuzzy boundaries and can be far less tangible. For example, Connecticut taxes computer services _ a potentially broad sector _ and thus tried to tax hotel reservations, since they rely on computers. But the state's supreme court decided last year that the tax should not apply, because customers were paying for the reservations, not the computer service, Leon said. When asked how the state defines computer service, Leon said: ``We're still grasping with that.'' Also, administering the tax becomes highly complex when levying transactions a multi-state business has with another multi-state firm. Roger Feldman, chairman of Gaston & Snow, a major Boston law firm with offices around the country, predicted Massachusetts businesses would take their legal work outside the state to skirt the sales tax. Firms are likely to shift some of tasks to out-of-state offices. ``We'll try every legal means to avoid paying the tax,'' Feldman said. Tax experts say political inertia is a major factor working against service taxes. ``For most politicians and taxpayers, an old tax is a good tax,'' said a report delivered last month to the Federation of Tax Administrators, a national group of state tax officials. ``In substance, this position argues that known evils are better than unknown evils,'' the report said. New Mexico is one state without such worries. Its original sales tax from the Depression included a tax on services, said Carolyn Lindberg, economic analyst with the New Mexico Taxation and Revenue Department. As a result, New Mexico taxes most services, excluding sales made by non-profit institutions. ``It's accepted,'' Lindberg said, though she added, ``it comes as a shock to newcomers.'' States that have tried more recently to adopt service taxes have used more of a laundry list approach, identifying various services to be included but omitting others. For example, Massachusetts' plan exempts management consulting services, even though accounting is included. Business and tax experts criticize this process, saying it may meet political expediency but does not make economic sense. ``Everyone believes the future will have a different combination of taxes,'' said James Howell, former chief economist at Bank of Boston. ``But you can't draw it up in an arbitrary and pernicious way.''

DOC.HEAD: As Layoffs Increase, Companies Seek Legal Advice
DOC.TEXT: An employee signs a waiver promising not to sue for age discrimination in return for a better severance package, then turns around and sues anyway. A sinking retailer tells a federal bankruptcy judge it needs to close a third of its stores and lay off 18,000 employees to survive. The judge rules that the retailer must negotiate with the workers on a severance package. Faced with increasingly complex labor laws and the need to trim work forces in a souring economy, many companies are seeking legal advice on how to lay off workers, lawyers say. ``The advice is simple _ be careful,'' said Felix Springer, an attorney at Day, Berry & Howard, a Hartford law firm that developed a seminar on how to lay off employees to satisfy a flood of corporate inquiries on the subject. More than 120 corporate executives attended the seminar this spring in Hartford and Boston. Citing attorney-client confidentiality, the law firm wouldn't disclose the names of companies that sent representatives. Other law firms say they too are spending more time counseling corporate clients on steps they can take to reduce their work forces without opening themselves to wrongful termination or discrimination lawsuits. ``It's a big issue. As the economy has turned sour, it's getting to be more and more of our practice,'' said Henry Stewart, a labor and employment lawyer at the Boston firm Palmer & Dodge. New England is a focus of the trend because of its sagging economic fortunes, and Connecicut is a prime example. Its unemployment rate rose to 5.7 percent in April, surpassing the national rate for the first time in 13 years. Nearly 30 percent of 480 companies that answered a recent survey by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association said they expect to reduce their work forces within the next three months. Springer said his firm advises managers to choose workers to be laid off based on objective criteria including job performance, the value of their work to the company, length of service and education level. Companies also are urged to offer employees assistance in finding new jobs, as well as generous severance packages when possible, he said. Workers who feel they've been treated unfairly most commonly invoke two laws: The federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which covers those 40 and older, and Title 7 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits employers from discriminating because of race, religion, sex or national origin. But workers also are finding new and innovative ways to protect themselves. More and more companies are asking employees to sign waivers promising not to sue for age discrimination in exchange for extra benefits, usually an enhanced severance package. That didn't stop two former employees from suing the Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of New York for age discrimination. They claimed they were told they wouldn't receive an enhanced severance package after being let go unless they waived their right to sue under the age discrimination act. The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, already concerned about such waivers, joined the suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Bridgeport last year. Congress is considering legislation that would limit employers' ability to offer extra benefits in exchange for an employee signing a waiver, said Paul Brenner, an EEOC attorney who specializes in age discrimination cases. ``It has become a very serious problem _ that is, that it's cheaper to buy someone out with a waiver and then not have to worry about a lawsuit,'' Brenner said. An estimated 18,000 employees expected to lose their jobs when Ames Department Stores Inc. closes 221 stores this summer recently won the right from a federal bankruptcy judge to negotiate with Ames management on a severance package. The move could have lasting impact. Analysts said bankruptcy proceedings could change dramatically if employees are made a party to such negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Contract Talks Open This Week For Big Three Automakers
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Big Three automakers open labor contract talks this week, with the companies worried about declining profits and Japanese competition and the union stressing job security. The United Auto Workers union begins talks Wednesday at General Motors Corp., Thursday at Ford Motor Co. and Friday at Chrysler Corp. The three national contracts covering more than 450,000 auto workers expire at midnight, Sept. 14, the first time in 11 years that all three expire at the same time. Each of the Big Three is cutting costs, and it's likely the union will be asked to pay a greater share of rising health and retirement benefits. Before benefits, an average UAW assembler is paid nearly $15 an hour. Anthony St. John, Chrysler's chief negotiator, has said that just maintaining the benefits in the current contract would boost Chrysler's labor costs 16 percent. Chrysler is in the worst financial shape of the Big Three. The union will tell management that protecting existing jobs is its top priority. Health and safety on the job, wages, time off and pension improvements also are on the list. The union has not had a strike since 1985, but the prospect this year has union members edgy. Families are paying off debts, holding off on big-ticket purchases and socking away whatever money they can. ``I try to expect the worst and hope for the best,'' said Gary Sorrell, president of UAW Local 977 at General Motors Corp.'s Marion, Ind., metal fabricating plant. He said he and his wife, Joyce, canceled this year's vacation. The UAW left the signing ceremonies of the last contracts bragging it had won job security because the companies were allowed to close plants only when sales of the product made there fell. Since 1988, however, GM and Chrysler have used that clause to close six assembly plants, putting 17,000 workers on the street. The Japanese in the same period have opened three U.S. assembly plants and announced plans for expansion of another. In June 1988, the Big Three's combined share of the nation's car and truck market was 74.4 percent. The Japanese companies held 19.2 percent. During the next two years, the Big Three lost nearly 3 percentage points. The Japanese gained almost 5 points. ``You have to treat plant closings as you do a national disaster,'' said Franklin Sherman of UAW Local 1005 in Parma, Ohio. ``You're talking about 3,000 or 4,000 people losing their jobs.'' The UAW set its bargaining agenda at a convention in May; President Owen Bieber pleaded with delegates to give bargaining committees broad flexibility. Yet, there was militant talk at the convention. It's widely believed GM will be targeted for a strike this year. Auto analyst Ron Glantz of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco calls a strike against GM likely. John Kirnan, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York, said chances for a widespread strike are better this year than in the past 20 years. The last nationwide strike by the UAW against an automaker was in 1985 when about 70,000 Chrysler workers walked out for 12 days. Negotiations usually start slowly. Bargainers meet through July and August in subcommittees focusing on contract clauses dealing with specific issues. Sometime around Labor Day, the UAW chooses one of the companies as a target. Talks at the other two companies are suspended until settlement with the target is reached. That contract then is taken to the others, modified slightly and brought to the rank-and-file for a vote. But so-called pattern bargaining may disappear this year. Chrysler, which reported an 80 percent decline in first-quarter earnings, is seen as most likely to break the pattern. During its financial crisis in the early 1980s, Chrysler extracted concession contracts from the UAW. Finances are better at GM and Ford, but GM's first-quarter profits this year were 54 percent below last year. Ford's were down 69 percent. Another factor in this year's talks is the aging work force and the increasing number of retirees. The average age of the Big Three auto workers is 42, compared with under 30 in the Japanese plants. Demands for retiree cost-of-living protection has led to numerous protests by older union members; another such demonstration is planned for Wednesday morning outside GM headquarters. Wally Kijek, a member of Local 1005 in Parma, said that cost of living adjustments, or COLAs, for retirees ``could be the ultimate end to that job security issue. The guy who is growing into retirement right now can rest assured that he will have an equitable wage when he gets out there.''

DOC.HEAD: Allegheny International Lawsuit Settled
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc. has taken a major step toward emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as a judge approved a $50 million settlement of a creditor lawsuit. The $1.3 billion suit was filed against Allegheny International's bank lenders by the company's unsecured creditors. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Joseph L. Cosetti late last week called the proposed settlement fair, reasonable and essential to the small-appliance manufacturer's chances of emerging from bankruptcy. The banks will make no cash payments. But they agreed to give up their right to receive $39 million of the $57 million in interest their loans to Allegheny International accrued from the company's Feb. 20, 1988, bankruptcy filing through Feb. 29 of this year, plus all interest accrued after that date. Interest has accrued at the rate of about $2 million a month. Allegheny International, which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances, has paid no interest, because such payments are not permitted while under bankruptcy protection. It is to make the payments once it emerges from bankruptcy. The interest being forfeited by the banks will be given to unsecured creditors and shareholders in the forms of stock and warrants. The banks also agreed to absorb their legal fees, for which they usually could receive reimbursement from Allegheny International. Allegheny International, meanwhile, agreed to provide legal indemnity of up to $3 million to the banks arising out of other claims that could arise from deals that prompted the suit. The creditors, who later were joined by shareholders, claimed in their May 1988 complaint that institutions led by Mellon Bank doomed the company to bankruptcy, at the expense of other creditors, when they forced the company in 1986 to accept a harsh new loan agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh: No Criminal Evidence Against Neil Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf pvs, bgng: ``We need ...'' to CORRECT name of TV program; picks up 7th graf pvs, bgng: ``Following the...'' A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Sunday he has no information that Neil Bush, President Bush's son, participated in criminal activity in his role as director of a failed savings and loan in Colorado. But Thornburgh insisted the Justice Department would pursue any case against the 34-year-old Bush if it receives credible allegations of criminal misconduct. In the meantime, the attorney general added, it would be unfair to appoint an independent counsel to investigate Bush, as some House Democrats have suggested. ``I don't think it would be fair to anyone, any citizen of the United States to appoint an independent counsel ... where there is not allegations of criminal misconduct,'' he said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. Ron Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said there wouldn't be any talk of independent counsels if Thornburgh and Justice Department officials were doing their jobs on the S&L debacle. ``We need presidential leadership. We need leadership from the do-nothing Justice Department. ... We've got to clean up this mess,'' he said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' Following the NBC broadcast, Thornburgh retaliated in a statement issued by his office. ``Mr. Brown is either sadly misinformed or purposefully distorting the record,'' Thornburgh said. The Bush administration, he said, has more than doubled the number of investigators or prosecutors, set up 27 task forces and, in the last 21 months, indicted 329 people in the S&L crisis. Elsewhere Sunday, Republicans and Democrats traded charges over who's to blame for the S&L cleanup, which may cost taxpayers as much as $500 billion. While attention has focused on Neil Bush because of his father, leaders of both political parties said he is simply a symbol of a greater systemic failure. In general, Republicans have accused the Democratic-controlled Congress of thwarting previous efforts to clean up the S&Ls. Democrats have accused the Republican presidential administrations of lax supervision. ``Neil Bush is really not the issue,'' Brown said on NBC. Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, agreed. ``Neil Bush was a passenger on the Titanic when it went down,'' Rollins said on the NBC program, adding: ``I think he was a little naive, obviously, but he didn't cause the savings and loan (crisis).'' But Thornburgh said information turned up in other investigations of Neil Bush's role as a director of the Denver-based Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association might be turned over to the Justice Department. So far, ``Nothing has been brought to our attention that indicates criminal activity,'' he said. ``Let me assure you, however, that in this case as in any other that if there are credible allegations of criminal wrongdoing, we will pursue them.'' Bush has been charged by thrift regulators with violating conflict-of-interest rules for, in one case, accepting a loan from a businessmen who later received a $900,000 line of credit from Silverado. Bush has denied doing anything wrong and will appear at an administrative hearing in September to defend himself. In addition, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is investigating the $1 billion failure of Silverado to determine whether Neil Bush and other directors acted in a diligent manner. Charges could be filed against Bush if the FDIC determines there was negligence. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said she will not abandon her push to force Thornburgh to appoint an independent counsel to investigate Silverado. However, she is one person short of the 12 members of the House Judiciary Committee needed to request an attorney general to appoint a special counsel. But Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., said if an independent counsel were assigned to the Silverado case, there would be a need for similar investigations into, for instance, Democratic Sen. Alan Cranston's acceptance of hundreds of thousands of dollars from Charles Keating, head of a failed S&L in California. William Seidman, chairman of the FDIC, said on CBS the Silverado case was being handled ``like every other case'' of a failed institution. The FDIC, which insures the commercial banking system, is ``under stress,'' Seidman warned. ``It's at a low point in history as a percentage of what it's insuring,'' he said. ``And we can handle anything we can foresee right now, but if things come along, major failures that we're not able to foresee at this time, that would be another story.''
